In any case, fatigue is a concept in training that many people have an intuitive understanding of, but I was lucky enough, bragging time to get a formal education and sport science, PhD and all that stuff. So we studied fatigue for a very long time. And here's something that we learned that some people don't know. And it is this. There is something called physiological fatigue where it's just like your cells are getting beat up. Your bones, micro fractures when you lift really hard, your blood vessel sometimes burst a little bit. Your muscles get torn, tendons, connective tissues, all that stuff. And that's kind of obvious. Like after you do a few sets of 10 in the squat, you don't have to be a rocket scientist to be like, something is broken inside me and hopefully we'll get fixed at some point. Try to walk up the stairs or down the stairs like, my body, my body has sustained damage. And that makes sense. And that's definitely a thing. But there's another fatigue that stacks on top of that, which is psychological fatigue. Your brain is a machine. It's a thinking machine. And during it's thinking processes, if you force it to think really hard or focus psychologically and create a lot of psychological stress, it also accumulates both physical awareness and care. For example, some of your neurotransmitter pools can get heavily reduced such that the transmission through various neurons are from one to another. Isn't as reliable as it always is. It's kind of when you feel spent, like at the end of a three hour long squat workout, your brain is tired. Someone's like, try hard at anything. And you're like, ugh, I can't, right? That psychological fatigue is also a separate layer to the physical fatigue. Here's the trippy part. Psychological fatigue, there are two more things to say about it. One is you can sum up psychological fatigue from other sources that are not training. You can get physiological fatigue from training or from like spending all day on your feet. Like that, who absolutely physiological fatigue is well, even though it's not training. So you know that when you're going hard on the gym, you have to make sure to manage your physical activity, not doing any kind of super stressful work. If you're really serious about training, you got to try to work around, minimize, etc. so that you can pour everything you have into training. Psychological fatigue absolutely comes from other sources. In the main fact, much of it may come from other sources. If you have a really stressful day at work, you come home and you yell at your partner for a little bit, you can't believe I'm saying partner, 2023 shows this, your wife, man, like, God intended. If you do that, that may sum up more psychological fatigue than three hour long psychotic squat workout ever could. That's the first point about psychological fatigue is it comes from a bunch of different sources, mostly your daily life. And then secondly, psychological and physiological fatigue mix and affect each other into total fatigue. So here's the big point there. If you have physiological fatigue that you have accumulated, as you rest and recover physically, like you move less. Over time, that physiological fatigue starts to drop off. Perfect, your body's healing itself. How if during that time, you're stacking a lot of psychological fatigue on top. And that psychological fatigue is high and continuing, like as you go Monday through Thursday through the week from your first leg workout on Monday, everyone knows Monday's leg workout. To your second leg workout Thursday, physiologically under the hood you're healing. But if that entire week is finals week at school, you're breaking up with your girlfriend who had a misunderstanding and killed your dog so you're grieving for Wolfie. And at the same time, your boss is like one millimeter away from your face while you're working. And he's like, you better do these goddamn spreadsheets right or god, damn it, you're like, do I have a drill sergeant? Boss, how does that work? I thought I worked for a software company. And all of that psychological fatigue is high and not reducing because it's just continuously being presented Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. Your degree of healing physiologically, your tissues in your legs, the healing will slow down a ton so that by the time you get to Thursday, you may still be under recovered, where normally you would be totally fine. And it wasn't because you were more active. It wasn't because your nutrition was off. You may even have gotten just as much sleep as usual. It is because your psychological fatigue infects and bleeds into it affects your physiological fatigue and importantly, your ability to bring down that physiological fatigue. And in training, if you give a shit, your ability to train hard to provide adequate nutrients and to bring that fatigue of hard training down as fast as completely as possible between sessions is kind of the trifecta of getting really good results. How do you know you're doing the right stuff to nearly guarantee most of your results will be unlocked? Well, don't worry. We have a three point list in training. The basics means the following things. First, your technique is that at least targeting the muscle that you want. You're getting a pump and a burn and tension in the target muscle. And the technique doesn't wreck your joints to where you can't do the same exercise two weeks in a row because you're too beat up. Anything within that is good. Now there's always the better and better technique, but at least technique that's stimulus target muscle and doesn't wreck the joints. You may have gone to the average gym and seen maybe about 25% of people, not even check those two boxes. You'll watch a lady doing something with a cable and you're like, exactly what muscle does she think that's working? Who knows? You can watch somebody deadlift with the most crooked shit you're ever seen. You're like, that guy's never going to be back at the gym because he's going to be living at the hospital from now on. So make sure you get those two right. That our technique is better, but at least make sure you're hitting the target muscle and not just having instant injury results. Next, your relative effort has to be high, which means you have to be pushing the bar or the cable or the dumbbell to where it slows down in your sets regularly. If you can do a set of 10, same pace, put down, walk off. You're not training hard enough. You are not hitting the basics. But if you get even one rep until that grind zone, you're good to go. You're going to be getting a lot of results and a big fraction of the results you've got coming to you anyway with genetics and some of the other variables. If you intend on continuing to make things challenging, as you get stronger, the amount of weight and the reps required to get you to grind will go up. So this automatically takes care of progression. As long as you're training with a high relative effort, getting into that grind zone for your working sets on average, progression takes care of itself. Next is volume. Very simple. At least two to three sets per muscle group per session and frequency is at least two sessions per week. Two to four sessions per week and three to ten sets per muscle group per session. If you just about the optimum results per any muscle group that you want to train. If you want to get really big legs and you tell me you're relative effort as high your technique is decent. Next, what does it mean to have a basically good diet that will get you most of the results you got coming to you? Three to six high protein meals per day, non-agosiable. When you're trying to gain your eating in a calorie surplus and thus gaining when you're trying to lose fat, you're eating in a calorie deficit and thus losing fat. Most of your eating is in healthy foods, which is to say lean meats, veggies, fruits, whole grains and healthy fats. If you're not eating total junk food all the time and one meal a day with no protein, you're well on your way. How do you make sure you get the basics of good recovery? Well, it's really not that many things. First, you get enough sleep. Seven to nine hours on average, but enough to feel rested. Lower psychological stress environment, just try not to be in a divorce 24-7. Lower physical stress environment, if you want to get really jacked legs, don't also be a marathon runner. The take home here from this entire chat is that if you just do a good job with these basics as listed in this presentation, you'll get most of the gains over time that your genetics allow. So, to the exercises, let's talk about how to choose exercises. There are a few rules, I'd say five, in how to choose your exercises. Five rules about how to choose your exercises. First, you want to think about what exercises give you the best SFR stimulus to fatigue ratios. That's super fancy signs talk for exercises that whenever the target muscle is, let's say it's the chest. Exercise is that give your chest a ton of tension through the chest as you do them versus like, I don't know, I don't really feel my chest a ton. A ton of burn, especially at high reps like torching your shit. Huge pumps from not so many sets always a good sign. Your target muscle feels exhausted as shit versus like, man, I don't know, I can keep going this exercise seemingly does nothing to me. And also gets you plenty or as much as your genetically capable of in that regard of delayed onset muscle soreness or just muscle soreness after the training. Like, if you are a leg press for your legs, gives you crazy tension, burn, pump, exhaust the crap out of your quads and your quads get so far for a few days after, she gets kind of a winner. That's not that's the stimulus side. The fatigue side is it doesn't beat up your joints at ton and every single exercise you can do for every single muscle can be ranked somewhere on how much it beats up your joints all the way from super low. I can't even tell to like, if I do this, I will just get joint cancer and I'll never recover and I'll never have joints again. Technically, you want to pick the ones that are nice on your joints. You want the exercise also to not dump a ton of psychological fatigue onto you. Psychological fatigue can come from having a try really hard, which is a part of training, but if you needless they have to try hard to get the same you're better off at an exercise when you don't want to have to go psychotic, but you get a great stimulus anyway. And also a part of psychological fatigue and really a big part is how fun and enjoyable the exercises. So if you if you bench press works well for you, so the deficit pushups, which is love deficit pushups, and that is absolutely a factor, a huge factor, but it's a meaningful factor and has been vetted in the research actually, is being a predictor of success, if you actually like the exercise you're doing. So that's number one. Number two is you want to choose what you think you can progress on slowly. Progress is critical. It's the foundation of training. And if you have muscle groups in which you pick an exercise for them and that exercise is like, you do it. It's a good workout, but then the next week it's not a great workout and you stop getting strong pretty fast. Just doesn't gel with you. But if you know from past experience that if you start squatting, you just add the pounds and pounds to your squat over weeks and weeks and weeks, that is going to grow a ton of muscle growth over long terms. I would pick something like that. Third rule is if you're building your plan maybe for the first time or maybe for the 10 trellian of time, people will always say not always people sometimes say often, maybe too often, that like you've got to switch it up man, keep the body guessing. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Periodization. Let's talk about controversy, virtue signaling, fitness coaches. No way. That's a myth. JK, they're real. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pre-Dization, and today's video I'm going to weigh in on a bit of fitness controversy that's kind of happening in the social media space, and that is weight loss drugs versus lifestyle choices. And I think this is a false controversy. I think it is a false dichotomy, and I'll be very clear about this in nine points. Let's get to the point. So here's the thing to set this up. There is a new generation of weight loss drugs out on the market FDA proved more and more people are using them. They are GLP1 and GIP agonists. These are gut hormone gut peptides. And these drugs with the most famous of which, just the first really effective one is known as OZEMPIC, aka semagletide. There's also a trazapatide, and it's coming out with all kinds of new drugs on the horizon. And what these drugs do is they do a few things, actually very good for your health in general, and seemingly from all the research we have and all the inference from my pathways they activate and how. And but their biggest thing is so small stuff is they improve insulin sensitivity and also other stuff. But their big major beneficial effect is that they absolutely crush appetite. Now to be more technically correct, they have a very powerful dose-dependent effect on appetite. So if you take very little amount of the drug, you get a slight reduction in appetite. Well, that's okay, whatever. If you take much more of the drugs, you can take enough of the drugs in a safe and healthy manner. This has been tested over and over on large groups of people. Even huge doses of the drug relative to how much they crush hunger are totally safe. And that's the thing is when I say huge doses, it's a very small amount of actual stuff. And it can make your appetite basically just go away. We don't want appetite to go away because we still want people eating food. But as you can imagine, if we tight-rate the drug appropriately in a particular patient that's taking it, we can kind of set their hunger levels at gee anything we want. So if you're normal hunger level, as you're consuming 4,000 calories a day and thus you're overweight and in bad shape, we can give you just enough drug to get you down to 2,000 or 2,500 calories. The reason I say this is a lot of folks have told me in the past that came my squat, as having some trouble. I watched them squat, and kind of every rap looks a little different. Not a little different, like, enough different to where I'm like, oh, you mean this mistake on this right? And that mistake on that right? Every set looks different. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for our sounds for your decision. I have a quick tip for you. The quick tip is that in the gym when you are coaching yourself and especially other people that you are helping with their fitness, simple cues work best. Here's the deal. If you're coaching yourself or others, it is always tempting for some segment of us to try to be as advanced as possible with arguing and then using exotic, multi-layered cues to try to get the person to shift into the technique that we would like to see. So something like, you know, try to twist your pinkies up and out and then the Glenwooden Humanity will join. Masses 164 degrees and Cheryl Rotation. It's like, what the fuck? And if you follow some insta people, I will not name them. That's the kind of advice they give. You're like, whoa, this person is really smart and must know what they're talking about. But here is the reality. Most exercise moves are actually quite simple. Sport moves are very complex. Kicking a soccer ball properly has a ton of different rotations and joining us, et cetera. Bench pressing a bar, squatting, deadlifting is some of the simplest moves you can describe in biomechanics. And here's the even more important part. Humans learn best when simple instructions are given. You want the instructions you give to your clients to allow them to move better. You want them to be understandable so that they can allow people to move better. You don't need the instruction to have the added benefit of making you sound really smart. Because your job is to be a service provider to them to get them to move better so they can be fitter and healthy and all the stuff they pay you money for. They don't really pay you money for you to sound smart. And if sound being smart came at no additional expense of conveying information, hey, fucking smart it up, do you house or whatever the fuck? But if sounding smart, layers in a needless layer of complexity, layers in the layer, who said that better, if sounding smart adds a layer of complexity that obfuscates the actual goal and interferes to some extent with efficient effective communication, you are literally trying to sound like a fucking nerd at the expense of the benefit to your client. Don't do that. That doesn't make any sense. Before a set that applies, after a set that applies. If you're emailing instructions to your client when you watch their video on Luma, whatever your distance coaching, that applies. During the set, we've of course you give a few cues here and there. During the set, people are focused on the set and they're in pain and they're exhausted. So the cues you give during a set have to be even simpler, chest up, shoulders back, elbows up. Don't external internal supination, the fuck up outta here. What is this in an anime class? It's cool, nerds shit is cool. But if it interferes with message delivery, it's not a good idea to do. It's just not the best time for people to process complexity. If at all. So my recommendation is to use the simplest cues that work. No simpler. You don't want cues that are so simple. They're ineffective. What is that, thank god, all right, fake Albert Einstein quote, like, make everything you can as simple as it can be, but no simpler. Right. So that is definitely a thing that applies and only elevate the complexity of your explanation when that is required to deliver the information within your explanation. If you can deliver the same amount of information, get the person to understand the same thing and fix the technique that they need to with the smallest amount of information. But there's also a certain number of, well, anything, but pushups per day that you can do. When it tires you out so much and it taxes your recovery abilities so much that you could get better doing less volume. Another hint is if your muscles are chronically still sore before you hit them again. If you train hamstrings on Monday and Thursday and on Thursday, you're still brutally sore from what you did Monday. You're still trying to train through that soreness. And in the middle of that process you're saying we got to go again. That's almost by definition doing too much volume. But in any case, if your muscles have plenty of time to heal and where they don't get super sore, you know, you might be overreaching, but not a super big concern. But if you're hammering your muscles before they've had a chance to recover and you're doing this often, you're probably at least doing too much volume versus what you could be to optimally. Another one is especially before those many deloads you have to take too often. Your mind muscle connections starts to feel a little bit off. Your technique feels a little bit off. It just feels like it's too much stuff. That's a hint that maybe too much stuff. And another last little hint to yourself as to if you're experiencing this, if it's high rep sets of 20 to 30, you can add a rep and a load here and there and still progress. But if it's lower up sets, that's a 5 to 10, 10 to 15 with heavier weight. You're having a big time progressing. The reason that's the case is as you train with very high volumes, possibly too high, your muscle fibers start to change from being acting like the average slower twitch faster twitch combo fibers to more of the fibers that used to act in a faster twitch manner starting to act in a slower twitch manner. And slower twitch muscles as they adapt, their endurance goes up real fast, which is why you get really good at doing high reps and you can progress at high reps. But they're cross sectional area, they're size and their strength doesn't change nearly as much. The Smith machine can allow you to push your feet, let's say, in a squat. Smith machine squat. You can push your feet so far ahead of yourself with decent amount of weight that you end up tip-y toe unstable squatting it, because otherwise you would just like fall back through the machine. That much strain on your knees when you're not used to it, can mess you up. The other hand, if you squat on such a way that you didn't step through enough forward into the machine and your feet are too far back, that squat ends up leveraging your back. And you're in your hips and your spine at ton, and that it puts way more stress in that area. And it's not like stress in that area as bad. Another machine that we see a little bit more danger with than many others is the Hacksquat. Why? The Hacksquat is one of those machines that is a way harder at the bottom than at the top, which means it's a really good pie purtrophy. Like it's optimally angled to make you get really, really, really, really, gyanquat. Huge tension at the stretch, minimal tension at the top. But if you can't get out of the bottom, you're kind of stuck. And a lot of Hacksquat's go pretty deep, and so if you're stuck there for long enough, you know, I'm not going to get rotest-care, but not so great things can happen. All sorts of really messed up. Neonjuries hit injury, spine injury, so on and so forth. The solution here is to have a spotter or two for heavy low RAR sets. You might be able to do most of your sets for the day, totally fine on your own, especially if you know what you're doing. Number four, is a gym machine you might not see very often. It comes from the world of equipped powerlifting, but it does have its place in hardcore gyms, across the country, and sometimes people use it wrong, you get into some shit. It's called the monolith. It's a machine that has these hooks that hang down and hold the bar. And then you unwrapped the bar, you don't move anywhere, your buddy hits the lever for the monolith. The hooks swing out, you do your squats, you come back off, you go, okay, I'm good, rack, and then the hooks swing back in, and then you just put the weight down. The problem with that machine is, once the rack swings out, you're on your own, and unwraking it can feel really weird if you're used to walking it out. Just standing there and you're like, oh shit. And if you want to walk it back in, once you put the bar back in, the hooks a lot of times will shake, and sometimes the weight will pop back out of it. So if you're not used to using a monolith, don't just go in there and use it, just be like, oh, it's fine, it's just like any other piece of equipment. Half some respect, because a monolith can put you into the ground. There are solutions to this. A lot of really good monoliths nowadays, will have chains or belts that catch the weight. So if you have to dump, it's possible to dump her, if you just sit down the weights will catch no problem. Another thing is almost every time that you use a monolith, you need at least two, possibly three technical spotters that are competitive power lifters have been around a long time, they know how to spot the monolith. Because the amount of weight you can lift out of a monolith is really high. The amount of things you can go wrong is really impressive, and so you want spotters and supportive chains or supportive belts to make sure that if you do go south, things happen. Learning how to use a monolith properly from really good power lifters, before going heavy and hard on it, is a really, really good idea. It's one of those things that you need, probably to be associated with a lifting crew for, and not just do by yourself. Lastly, I'm going to get some shit for this, but this is a true fact. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Creation. Today's video is the five rules of bicep training, helpful tips to get you the biggest bicep that you can get. They're not hard rules, but give them a try and they'll probably work. Rule number one is to try the free motion bicep curl and or the inclined dumbbell curl. In the way you do the free motion handle, you walk away in front of the machine. So at the bottom your biceps are pre-stretched out like crazy and then you curl from a very stretched position. And of course, this is the same position and up taking on an inclined dumbbell curl where you put the inclined 45 degrees or 60 degrees or so. And at the bottom you're going to have an unreal stretch your biceps attach across your shoulder as well as your elbow. So if you push this upper arm back before you start, it really stretches them out. There's been good deal of research and plenty of theory showing that you get more muscle growth when you stretch the muscle under load versus if you just load without a stretch, these two exercises and there's a few more you could try the stretch of the muscle are really awesome. Up until I tried them, I didn't think there was a great bicep exercise for me, just some good ones and mostly mac and okay ones that I didn't love too much. Now I have go to exercises that are red and butter, gonna mess me up every single time. Rule number two on the front of messing up. A lot of people can even do good technique with curls, but way too many people drop the bar really quick because the eccentric slow control in the way down is two things. Painful and reduces how many reps you could do or how much weight you can do. So that girl who's always looking at you in the gym who you think is maybe single, maybe interested maybe satanic and gonna kill you. She is just not looking as hard anymore because you used to use the 25s but now you're down to tens and change because you're trying to control these centric. But picking up Satanist tricks at the gym aside, it's just better for muscle growth. So when you have the incline dumbbells, you bring up the dumbbells, don't just throw your thrash them back down, bring it up as half the battle, maybe not even half because that's the easy part. The hard part is to take two or three seconds slowly control all the way down at the bottom and then bring back up again. That is critical. Rule number three, especially on dumbbells. You want your pinkies to end up towards the sky. As you curl, I don't mean you have to rotate, but as you curl, think pinkies up. The biceps have two functions. One is for our inflection, and one is supination. Moving a wrist like this. And pinkies up is the supinator cue. It can help you really get in tune with hitting your biceps versus all the other foreign flexors that can do the job instead. Rule number four is to experiment with different rep ranges. There is a huge variation in responses. Some people would do sets of eight in the bicep curls and I don't know, they just hurts my elbows and I don't feel anything. Some people would do sets of eight and say, there is a tension in my biceps. I cannot explain. And if I do higher rep sets of 15 and 20, I just feel tired. How you know which rep range is the right for you and there could be lots of ren answers is, if in the heavy rep range, you feel a ton of tension in the bicep itself. In the lighter rep ranges, you get crazy, crazy burns. If you have a psychotic burn right in the middle of the bicep, you're not doing anything wrong. We define overtreating as a consistent, reduction in train performance, lasting months, and is also difficult to reverse out of. That's not really anyone in the gym I've ever met. What you're looking for is not overtraining. That's way too late. You're looking for overtaking. Overreaching is when you temporarily exceed your recovery capabilities. And overreaching in the hypertrophy space has some signs and symptoms. The number one sign in symptom is are you unable to match your weight and reps from last week for at least two sessions for that muscle group in a row on every or almost every exercise. This fundamental feature which I'm about to subscribe to you is what makes the prime row and in fact many prime machines super super special. It's their three peg system. Depending on which peg you put more or less weight on is where the machine leverages to make it harder or easier in your range of motion. Generally speaking, if you put weight on this first peg as far as order as concerned, they name to peg number two. I'm not really sure why, but I'm sure that had a great reason. This peg right here replicates exactly that without hardly any tension at the other end. The middle peg generally gives you a feel that replicates something like a barbell row. It's just going to be pretty even beginning to end no big difference. Real good place to start for many people. This top peg, which I like to call the money peg, and sounds like money penny from James Bond. I always hate that name. But like you work for me, change that name, anything else, in any case. This peg is super, super interesting because the way training on this machine works is that if you put a ton of weight on this peg, the bottom part of the machine is super highly loaded at that deep stretch. And then the top part gets progressively less loaded as you pull so that you experience essentially no load at the very top. The really cool thing about that is that a body of research that's pretty old, but is accumulating in how much confirmatory research that is about this, is showing us that a lot more hypertrophy by a decent margin is caused by taxing the loaded stretch at the bottom of most muscle groups, and much less is caused at the top. Here's the thing, if you were to do a traditional barbell row, you may be able to get quite a few more reps at that bottom range, but you won't be able to touch your tummy after a while because it's much harder up here than it is down here. Thus, when you reach failure on Metros, yes, technically you reach failure, but that most productive bottom and range could have gotten you more reps and more stimulus. And of course, running, and this is something we'll hear a lot already heard a lot from, run focused, well-designed, long enough trials, and then publish all the data even the duds. There's a problem that sometimes people run a study, especially if it's corporate funded or if it's lab funded by someone with an ideological interest, then which is almost all the time, then the the studies and say what they want, they might just like shelve the study, not publish it, and then publish another study and said that comes up with good results. So you can see like half the time the results say doesn't do anything, half the time it says it does something a little bit. If you just don't ever publish the studies that say it doesn't do anything, you're like, oh my god, 95% of the study say it does something. It's called a file drawer effect. It's a really nasty thing in science and we should be steering really, really clear that sort of thing. Because something doesn't work is just as good of data as something does work. It tells us something about the world. Like if you use data from your visual field to figure out how room looks, there is not a 400-pound safe next to the door is just as good of data for you as there is a 400-pound safe over by the wall. It's good data either way, not having something somewhere is known thing. This doesn't improve your mood or your body composition or your health as far as the supplement goes is a really good data because then you could not buy it, not have to take it whereas if we only publish positive data we get a real distorted distorted mix of what's going on. First, you want to choose the right size for your deficit. And that means how many calories are you going to remove from your regular diet in order to lose the amount of fat that you want. Now, if you just took one pass at this question intellectually, you could say like, well, I want to lose a lot of fat. So what's the most I could safely do? There is a number for that for every individual, a little trial and error figure that out. And the thing is, what is safe? Isn't really sustainable? And you want to be able to sustain your efforts through the entire course of the diet to actually reach your goal. For example, it is actually a true statement that with this security protocols they have in place, going to Navy SEAL triodes as long as your doctor approves that your healthy is actually pretty safe. Yeah, I'm going to die. But is it sustainable? By definition, for almost everyone, it's the opposite of sustainable. You might not last a few minutes, never mind a few hours or days or the whole selection course. So you don't just want to pick a calorie number randomly out of the hat. Too much is too much and you'll fall off the wet. On the other hand, you could say, okay, hey, listen, listen, okay, I heard you. I'm going to pick a very small deficit to go real slow and steady. And at first, that looks like a good idea. It really does. A small deficit is easy to pull off. You won't be unsuccessful with it in the straightforward way of just burning out. But research shows people get less success with a very small deficit because they reached the following problem. Week after week after week, they look at their body. They try to note how they feel. They see how they close fit and not much is changing. And technically, you're losing a third of a pound a week or something. You barely feel it in the diet fatigue wise. They're not super hungry. But how are you supposed to motivate yourself if kind of nothing's happening? Right? Imagine going out of road trips somewhere. What that means practically is a deficit of you trying to lose something like half a percent to 1% of your current body weight per week, which means if we think about this, let's say you weigh 200 pounds. And that means that if you lose a half percent per week, that's a pound per week, that roughly corresponds to a 500 calorie deficit from your current diet. 500 calories missing in some form of exercise increase, activity increase and usually mostly food reduction. The other hand, if you're on the top end, you're going to lose about two pounds a week. And that means you are going to be at 1% of weekly weight loss goal and that's roughly around if you do the math, a thousand calorie per day deficit, a thousand calories per day. If you're eating 3,000 calories normally to maintain your weight at 200 pounds, you could be eating 2,500 calories potentially or even 2,000 calories potentially in order to get to your goal. Both are totally fine answers and there's a lot of wiggle room. The wiggle room is something you decide when you're actually doing it. What you want to do is get a combination of two things. One sustainability, you've got to feel pretty energetic, pretty good, no crazy sleep loss, no crazy cravings at least in the beginning. And two, you've got to be like, wow, like I feel like I need a less food, I feel a little lighter day to day. And after one, two and three weeks, the weight is steadily going down as predicted. As long as you can check both boxes, generally speaking you're really good to go. Next tip number two is to make sure you're doing a good job balancing your activity slash cardio and your food intake. Because it's very easy to look at deficit and think, okay, I'll just cut all my food down by 500 calories and then hit that. I won't change my activity at all. It's also easy to think the other way around where you say, okay, I'm going to exercise for 500 more calories per day. I'm going to change nothing about how I eat and that's going to be totally fine too. And again, just like I said at the beginning of this video, technically on paper without exposure to the real world, both of those are valid options. There's nothing wrong with them on paper in which is a lot of white people who start and do diets and then don't have a lot of success or any success with the process. They don't lose the way that they want. They end up thinking, well, like I fucking cut the calories, like the stupid textbook told me to, but the stupid textbook might not be reading the right textbook and it might not be telling you everything about what you need to know. I'm about balancing that two factory equation. There is a better way to do it and here it is. First, find yourself a level of physical activity that is sustainable. Ideally, something a little bit higher than what you're used to. A lot of times, step trackers can do a real good job with this. Where you look at your step tracker, you also have one on your cell phone. And if you're walking about seven or eight thousand steps a day, you think, oh, okay, that's nice. Let me bump it up to a minimum of ten k steps per day. If you wanted to do a ton of cardio, you could. But that takes up a ton of time and it generates a ton of fatigue and cardio is a really hard for how not many calories at birth. So what you just want to do is do a little bit more activity than usual, but not a ton more. Maybe 12, 10 to 12 k steps a day. That's number one. The next thing is to go on the internet and find out how many more calories per day, at my body weight, is this increase in activity burning. And that's usually something like 100 to 200 calories. Nothing crazy. Then you see, okay, I wanted to get to 500 calorie deficit. I'm already burning 150 extra from physical activity. That means I need 350 extra calories to take out from food. That's it. So that's not that hard. Once you find that out, you can go and plug and play and then you have found the balance. That balance may change in the future. You made your initial cut like this, yes. Number four is one about which most people actually don't know and that makes it a little bit curious. Here's the deal. There is actually quite a bit of research on this and the research is as follows. If you eat the same macronutrients every single day, thus the same calories and you have the same calorie deficit, you can actually see detectable differences in how healthy and how lean and how energetic your diet makes you depending on which schedule of meals that you use and the big thing here is similarity. It seems like human bodies prefer something like four to six meals a day and not something like one to eight meals a day and if you're going to have one meal a day, every day should be one meal pretty much. If you're going to have eight meals a day which would be the same length convenient every day should have eight meals. But the similarity is the big part. Let's say you have four meals a day. Is it okay that some days you have three meals totally? Is it okay that some day you have five meals totally? Is it okay if you have some days one, some days four, some days eight? It's okay, but it's not nearly as good. Your body thrives on regularity. In addition to this, you want similar meal times every single day. Some days you have breakfast at nine a.m. Some days you have an at eight a.m. But not very often do you have breakfast at eight a.m. one day and then you wait until two p.m. to eat the next day. So meal timing isn't all-ter-important. But if you stick to a very similar timing schedule through the day, you're going to have much better results. Well, by a small margin anyway, and one that counts, then if you just do random sporadic shit. And you also want to have similar macro spreads throughout the day, which means generally if you train in the morning, keep training in the morning. Most days of the week. I wouldn't train in the morning and then train at night training the morning, train night. Sometimes look your schedule just demands that you do, and that's totally cool. But a lot of times, it's a really good idea to stay as stable as you can. They did not invent that exercise. They did it like many, many other people around the world had four decades. Now, let's get into the weeds of the refined technique. Technically speaking, the RDL is a variation of the stiff leg of deadlift. It is a type of stiff leg of deadlift, which is a broader category of potential ways of doing that exercise, but it's actually the most common way of doing that exercise, and it is probably in most cases the most proper technique. The stiff leg of deadlift is designed to hit mostly the hamstrings, and RDL style, which jimsmiths just described for us, is exactly almost exactly how most people would do it. It's nearly ideal. Now, I just said that the RDL is one type of a universe of stiff leg of deadlift, a spectrum of ways you could do that exercise. And so some of the stuff that was said in the way to do it, like stopping a few inches from the ground, we could critique and say, aren't there different ways of doing that? Yes. And here they are. First, all stiff leg of deadlift can vary on the degree of back arch. You can be ultra super archenier low back, or you can be even very rounded. Number two, they can vary in the degree of knee bend. You can have a significant amount of knee bend, or you can do technically speaking a stiff leg of deadlift with completely straight knees and everything in between. Number three, the degree of bar and hip travel, you can keep your hips relatively stationary and let the bar swing out really far. You can try to keep your hips stationary, this is very challenging, and keep the bar super tight to your legs. You can try to push your hips back really far as you descend and have the bar travel very far away from you as well, or most commonly, you have your hips travel really far back, and the bar stays very close to your hips and the rest of your body. Number four, depth differences. You can finish a stiff leg of deadlift at the bottom at just around or below the knees, or generally if you're very flexible, you can do them all the way to below the floor, which means you're standing on a platform or lifting with smaller weights, and those are deficit stiff leg of deadlifts. Number five is the grip. You can have a narrow grip or a wide grip or even a snatch grip. These are all variations on a theme of the stiff leg of deadlift, and the RDL is one subtype of the stiff leg of deadlift more generally. Now, there are a few other minor distinctions, and I'm sure I haven't even covered all of them, but here are some other things to think about. One is the degree of eccentric control. You'll notice that RDLs you descend relatively slowly, hypothetically you could do a stiff leg of deadlift to descend more quickly. Retracted versus rounded shoulders, you could have a stiff leg of deadlift where the shoulders just hang, you could have ones where you arch and pull back your scapulae the entire time. You can choose to pause in the bottom position or not to pause. You can touch the ground or not touch the ground, and about a million other smaller changes you could make. Now, because in my humble view, probably the best use of stiff leg of deadlifts is hamstring training, let's review what the best practices are for using stiff leg of deadlifts to train your hamstrings. How, when we change these variables, we just talked about that could be different between different approaches to the stiff leg of deadlift to actually train our hamstrings the best. Well, here it is. First, you'll see by the way, many of these most almost all overlap with how an RDL is described. First, you want to have anterior pelvic tilt, which means that you have a neutral back or an arch back, your hips are tilted up and back, that pre-stretch is the hamstrings allowing them to get into a more favorable position to be stimulated for growth. To, you have a slight knee bend, it means you're not going to be really uncomfortable with no knee bend at all, and you can produce a high-alotting situation for the hamstrings without concerns for safety. So that's really good. You don't want too much of a knee bend because the users have to move the bar a lot further to get the hamstrings actually stretched out. Number three, you want a slow descent to maximize that nasty eccentric hamstring stimulus and to stay safe. The hamstrings are a finicky muscle. If you guys have ever played sports, you know the hamstrings like to get injured every now and again, and those are really almost always nasty injuries. You don't want their poles, they're this, they're that. You want to go nice and slow because you lose nothing going slow, and you gain an extra margin of safety and even probably a bit of stimulus as well. Another advantage you're going slow on the stiff leg of the deadlift is your knees and hips tend to go off track because they counteract each other. If you go slow, you can always reinforce that you're still using your hamstrings and they're being pulled apart painfully. If you go quickly, you could do a thing where you do a wrap, you come back up and you're like, fuck, I bet my knees too much. But if you're going slowly, you can auto adjust, make micro adjustments, pushing your knees back, keep it in a forward, back and forward to keep the right amount of tension on your hamstrings. Number four, you want to descend deep enough to painfully stretch the hamstrings, which is where that advice for stop two inches above probably isn't the best advice in the world from the RDL proponents. Because if you're really flexible in hamstrings, stopping two inches above the ground can be just not enough of a stretch and you don't get really sore or make a ton of progress. But if you're in that case, you would want to do some deficit work and really go below the floor, so to speak. But if you have very poor flexibility in the hamstrings, then you'd have to round your back a shitload in order to get two inches above the ground. Once you round your back, your posterior pelvis, tilt into posterior tilt. It takes tension off of the hamstrings and then it's just not much of a hamstring exercise anymore. So really what you need to do is the height where you go to is the most auto regulated part of the stiff leg and deadlift and you go until you feel a deep painful stretch in the hamstrings, not much further than that, and definitely don't stop until you feel that deep painful stretch. The next critique is that it's not actually the stretch causing more growth. It's training a muscle where it's strongest, or simply put the concept of new mechanical matching. The principle of new mechanical matching simply states that you're bought in, or recruit the muscles that are best internally leveraged before an action. If, for example, your biceps are scrolling down here, it will recruit at the biceps all over the brachialis and brachioratialis for curling in this range of motion. Now, it's important to understand where this principle comes from and what is supposed to replace? It's supposed to replace hennaman's size principle, which dictates that your body will first recruit the smaller marines, the smaller muscle fibers, the full action, and then it's fatigue sets in, or as force production requirements increase, and then it will start recruiting larger threshold motor units, larger muscle fibers, faster twitch muscle fibers. The theory of new mechanical matching actually stems from something completely unrelated to hypertrophy, which is specifically inspiration, so actually breathing in, and two, engage muscles, specifically during very submax more walking. How this relates to hypertrophy is relatively unclear, and that's why for the time being, I'm not really convinced that new mechanical matching can explain why we see more hypertrophy from training muscles in the stretch. This stems from misunderstanding of sampling variants and how science works. Let's assume we know for a fact there's an effect size of 0.2. Just because of sampling variants, the observed effect size will cluster around 0.2, but maybe a bit lower sometimes. Or a bit higher. In fact, some studies will find zero effect. Some studies could even find a negative effect. But on average, the effect size is being observed will be around 0.2 for instance. That's exactly what we see with the research. If you put your feet too far back or too far forward in a Smith machine squat, you can really fuck up your back or really fuck up your knees, as you lose a degree of freedom with how the bar moves, and then like it just puts your back and knees into a shitty position. A position that is almost impossible to get into in a regular squat, that's free weight because if your knees feel weird, just shift your hips back and now it takes the stress off the knees. If the back feels weird, you'll shift your weight forward and the knees take the load. So you get an even distribution of load. You can't really aggravate stuff nearly as easily, but on a Smith machine, your bottom is locked, top is locked, and you could really get into a situation where you expose your joints in a not nice way. And you might not even know you're doing it until three weeks later, you're like, ffff, fucking hell those hurt. This sucks. So if you're using the Smith machine wrong, you might not know about it. So if you want to train for both at the same time, you might have to make some choices one way or the other that don't optimize one or the other thing. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for RP Strength. There is a technique difference between size and strength training that most people miss. Not because they're bad people, although many of them are actually bad people for no related reason. It's because folks get the two size and strength training very mixed up. And that's usually okay because they're both amazing. However, one little change in mentality and approach, especially as you get bigger and stronger and more advanced, can be a big deal for maximizing your muscle growth and in the other direction, a big deal for maximizing your strength gain ability. Let's take a look. Starting from the commonalities between size and strength training, which I want to emphasize are massive. The cross sectional area of your muscle, if we cut your bicep, this is terrible, down the middle, and scope into it and see how thick it is, that is the single biggest determining factor for size. It's the only factor for size and it's the biggest determining factor for strength. If you have a bigger muscle, it is going to be stronger, period, and muscle size in an absolute sense is like a car engine. Not all the eighths produce faster cars than v6s, but on average, the engine size is going to be the biggest determining factor. So cross sectional area, muscle size is a big deal, but in strength training, other factors come into play. The degree of brain and spinal and peripheral nervous system activity can help you become much stronger, even though it doesn't really affect your size at all. That's how compound lifters are often similarly sized, driven, small than bodybuilders, but they can lift more because their nervous systems are there to give you as much possible strength from that same amount of size as you can. And there are also architectural factors. It turns out that if you practice similar or the same lifts for a long time, weeks and weeks and months and months, your muscle fibers actually turn a little bit into the direction of force produced by that lift, which is why weight lifters who do lots of high bar squats are really good at high bar squatting because their nervous systems are really well trained for it. And because their muscle architecture shifts in direction and optimize their high bar squat, if you're a bodybuilder and you're doing leg presses, you're the leg extension, you're doing hacksquads, you're going to be really, really big and generally good at high bar squats, but that last 5, 10, 15% of strength is due to architectural and nervous system factors. And a 15% difference in strength is like you're a very good power lifter compared to your the best power lifter in the world. So nervous system and architectural factors add into strength training in a way they don't really add into size training. However, there are lots of other commonalities. And one of the biggest ones is both require you to train multiple times a week for the same muscle or movement and both require you to go hard. Or as Jeff Nipperd likes to say, haired. Let's see that's hot. Super hot. There are differences in training approach between size and strength. There's lots of commonalities. There are some differences in what we're trying to train, but the approach is going to be a bit different. Here are some really core differences in training that's not getting to the big difference in mentality and technique. Exercise selection. When we're training our glutes for hypertrophy, I mean, we really want to target the glutes. So we asked the question of which exercise are really targets the glutes. We don't really care about how much weight is on the bar necessarily or what exercises use in competition. Because there is no competition. Our hypertrophy training is just the outcome we want. So like a front foot elevated Smith machine lunge is an amazing glute exercise. But in power lifting, for example, and training for strength, we want to train for specific movements because that's how we test them. So dead lifts are excellent movement that also stimulates plenty of glute hypertrophy. Good god, plenty of glute hypertrophy, but maybe not optimally, however, does make you really really good at dead lifts. That doesn't mean you can't do front foot elevated lunges for hypertrophy work for power lifting. It doesn't mean you can't do deadless hypertrophy, but at some point, you might have to make a choice on the margins and targeting specific muscles is the goal of hypertrophy. Targeting specific movements is the goal of strength. You want bigger shoulders for hypertrophy. You want to make overhead press for strength and things like that. The second difference is in repetition range. The best way to get directly stronger is to train between sets of three and sets of six repetitions roughly, somewhere in that range, plus or minus. Sets of three to six are amazing basic strength builders. And if you want to build muscle size that converts a very well to be made stronger, then sets of five to ten, a probably the best hypertrophy range for strength application. Like if you're a power lifting and you need bigger legs, because you want to squat more, building your big legs with sets of five to ten is going to convert to bigger numbers on your squat, then building your bigger legs with sets of ten to 15 reps, for example. So three to six and five to ten four strength and then the kind of hypertrophy that maps really well onto strength. However, four pure hypertrophy anywhere between sets of five and sets of 30 reps close to failure is a really good five hypertrophy and the distinctions within those ranges are very nuanced and very situations specific. So there's a much broader range of hypertrophy training reps and they don't tend to be as low as strength training reps. So if you want to train for both at the same time, you might have to make some choices one way or the other that don't optimize one or the other thing. And lastly, a big programming difference between hypertrophy and strength training is going to be volume. Strength training benefits from a lower fatigue environment. And it's a amount of systemic fatigue that it causes because lifting heavy is a special kind of dub to your nervous system and other things. You're not you're going to accumulate more systemic fatigue doing it so you can't do as many sets. You don't need as many sets and you can't do as many sets. So anywhere between five to 15 sets per muscle group and or movement per week seems to be optimized for strength training for most people. So if you do a sum total of eight sets of some kind of squat per week, you're well in that range. For hypertrophy training, it's really more like 10 to 30, especially more like 20 to 30 and specialized programs. So if your chest just isn't growing and you've been doing sets of eight for the chest or sorry sets of eight, eight sets per week for chest, it's a great way to get your chest strong for sure. But to get it to maximum size, you can't want to flirt over 10 and then considerably over 10 especially if you ease in. And more simple way to say this is in most cases, strength training is going to require considerably less volume than hypertrophy training. Sometimes by as little as half of the volume, hypertrophy training may require double the number of worksets that optimizes it versus strength training. So if you're training for both, again, you might have to make some trade-offs and say, what am I really training for in the next mesocycler two? I'm going to lean in to more high volumes, higher reps and so on and so forth and maybe movements that are more targeted to the muscle and less targeted to the overall exercise competency. There is a difference in the goal as you approach any rep of an exercise with strength training versus hypertrophy training. And that goal is too fold for strength training. The goal is to move weight from point A to point B. For hypertrophy training, that goal is to stimulate the muscle. I sounds very similar but they're different enough for more advanced folks for to actually matter. In strength training, you want to use the technique and mentality that lets you lift the most amount of weight. In hypertrophy training, you want to use the technique and the mentality and I'll get to more about what those are later that hits the target muscle the hardest. Because remember on strength training, if you successfully squat 500 pounds, no one at the judges table asks you, did you feel it in your quads? Can you imagine that? We have Dylan the second camera child with us today. And you have a great thing to do. It's an awkward nickname, but we're working on it. Can you imagine if you did a squat? You're like, all right, I got 500 in the judges like, did you feel it in your quads? You're not really the red light in the squat. It's nonsense. It would never work like that. But if you did a lot of squat reps for hypertrophy and someone's I did your field, your quads are like, not really, well, that really is kind of a problem if you're trying to grow your quads. Because clearly some muscles are working, but your quads aren't the ones being pushed closest to the limit and they're not the ones that are going to be growing the most out of that movement. Maybe it's your glutes, maybe it's your adiatures, maybe it's your lower back. So here's another thing. The strength training approach to reflect those points makes the lift as easy as possible for however much weight you're using. When you're about to bench press for strength, you want each rep to feel as easy as possible. When a power lifter does a set of five with a new PR weight and he racks the weight and goes, that was easiest. His buddies are like, yes, that's success. But imagine in hypertrophy training, finishing a PR of leg press, rack in the weight, that was easiest. Your buddies are going to be like, cool, why did you leave the machine? Clearly you should be doing more reps or more load or doing a technique that exposes your target muscles more attention. This is what you want to say to your hypertrophy training buddies to your muscle growth buddies is to finish that set of leg press and be like, dude, my quads are cooked. That's winning at hypertrophy training. Those are different things. And so in size training, the size approach makes the lift as hard as possible for however much weight is used. You have a 20 pound dumbbell in your hands for curls. You're trying to make that dumbbell in the technique and mentality that you're using it as hard as possible on your biceps. Completely the opposite approach as for strength training, which is to make it as easy as possible to get from point A to point B and successfully complete the lift. If you mix those two at some point, you're not really sure what you're training for and for more advanced folks, that can be a bit of a problem because for strength training, then the kind of avoiding the muscle growth stimulus. And this doesn't happen often, but if you're trying to train for strength and you're really worried about which muscles are being activated, you are 1,000% overthinking the movement and you have to be athletic and smooth and coordinated instead. So to put this in other words, and kind of really unify these concepts, strength training follows the path of least resistance. With all of the muscles helping that could possibly help that lift. On the other hand, size training follows the path of most resistance for the target muscles. And we're not worried about what other muscles are helping and ideally not a lot of them helps. So that target muscle or muscles plural if it's two at a time that you're training have to be the ones bearing load, which is exactly the opposite of what you want in strength training. You want to spread the load out on strength training, you want to condense the load in hypertrophy training. That is a big deal for folks that are more advanced. How does this change their technique? How does this actually, where does the rubber hit the rope? For strength, you want to pick each technique of your lift to create the smallest individual range of motion at any joint as possible. All of the joints that you're doing, you want them to have the smallest range of motion and you want to avoid deep stretches at any of your joints. Think about what a conventional deadlift looks like, which muscle is getting a major stretch in the conventional deadlift. It's not your quads, you're a half squat position. It's not your adductors, they're not in a deep stretch. It's not your glutes, it's a half squat position. It's not your lower back because that's pretty straight. It's not even rounded over. There's almost no stretch on your lower back. And so there is no muscle getting a maximum stretch really on the conventional deadlift, which is a really good thing because muscles put into their maximum stretch are able to generate a lot of tension internally, but the external tension is much lower. And we don't want low external tension because external tension is the only thing that matters in strength training. So you want to spread the load out as much as possible and keep each muscle to as a little range of motion as possible. More muscles, each one operating at their strongest point instead of exposed at the very weakest point is how you submit enough to do as a much weight as possible. The opposite is true in size. The technique in size is to create the largest individual range of motion for the target muscle and to make sure that you position that muscle in a really deep stretch under load consistently. For example, this stiff leg at deadlift. In the stiff leg at deadlift, the glutes are working plenty. The quads are hardly working at all. The lower back's working not much. What's happening is the hamstrings are isolated. It's like some big dude walks up to you and for your friends are bar and he's like, hey you and everyone turns around. Because that means human learn strength training technique pretty fluidly, you teach them how to do the efficient technique that spreads the load of many muscles and they get it real quick and they can tell like when I'm inefficient I'm off-center, nothing good is happening. But your body tries to come back to that efficient technique where the hypertrophy training, when you're doing pack flies for example. You're going to start to limit that chest range of motion and you're going to start to close in on yourself because your body's a shit shit. I have to survive this exercise and get as many reps as I can. I can't expose myself like this. This is inefficient, but remember, inefficiency in a sense is what we're trying to do when I hypertrophy training. So how do we use the mind muscle connection to do that? Well, with strength training, you want two things. Good technique, overall which is practiced, spreading the muscles, spreading the load to all the muscles, and monster drive and athleticism. If you're thinking about how your quads feel during squatting for strength, you're thinking about the wrong thing altogether. You need to be thinking good technique and then just pushing as hard as humanly possible. And you're going to know that that is what you're doing when you feel out the path of least resistance. If you're coming out of the bottom of squat and it feels really hard, but if you push your hips back a little bit and starts to feel easier, follow the easy technique. The easier the movement feels rep after rep after rep, the more you're winning a strength training because you're being the most efficient and can thus use the most amount of weight and get the biggest PRs. For size, good technique is reinforced by the path of most resistance. So if you're curling in a certain way kind of into your body that feels like it's easier, if you curl more of an arc and out of your body, you're like, oh, this is way harder, good, good. You're supposed to make the technique more difficult when I perturb your training for that target muscle. And there's another way to cheat the system here and really detect if you're doing a good job stimulating the muscle. It is to feel out the max tension in the target muscle. If you curl in a certain way, you're like, if you're feeling my forearms, my delts a little bit, biceps feel fine, and then you change your technique for the better, you're going to feel as crazy deep tension in your biceps. That is how you know your winning. For stiff-legged, that lifts and hamstrings. You're going to know when your hamstrings being hit because at the very bottom stretch, you're going to be like, oh my god, my hamstrings, feel that going to tear apart, that's what you want. And for higher repetitions and hypertrophy training, the muscle that is burning is the one that is probably getting the most load. So if you're doing lunges in a way that burns out your quads at home, but your glutes feel okay, you might consider your technique a little bit differently, lean a little bit more forward, keep your hips back and far away from you during lunges. And all of a sudden, your glutes start burning more, your quads start burning less, and you know every single rep, you're trying to get max tension through that target muscle. You're trying to get me maximum burn at the end of the set for that target muscle, and you're trying to do the exercise in such a way that the technique is more difficult and the target muscle is feeling at the same time. You don't want to do a technique that's so difficult that the target muscle doesn't feel in anymore. That's like some internal rotator in your shoulders that's doing all the shit. That's no good, but if you can combine maximum difficulty and maximum target muscle tension and maximum muscle burn at the end of a set, this is a triple checklist you can use to ask yourself, am I really doing good hypertrophy training technique? Yes. And if you have any three of those things that you're doing strength training, you're doing strength training wrong. Strength training means no one muscle ever feels at a time. It means the path of least resistance is maximum, and to be completely honest, it means you're not even thinking about what muscles are feeling what? You're thinking about re-open full childhood memories. If you implement this technique especially for your size training, in which you are trying to get into the path of most resistance, you're trying to feel that tension in the target muscle, and you're trying to feel the burn towards the end of the set, how is this going to affect your results in the gym? We'll check this out. You can absolutely strength train your weight to massive size. People empower lifting and strongmen do it all the time, but that will require you to use heavier loads, because you're optimizing for heavier loads, and not optimizing for getting as much hypertrophy out of lighter loads as possible. So you need to be working at time with heavy loads and growing a lot, but you could be growing more in using lighter loads instead. These heavier loads over time will add chronic wear and tear and multiply your acute injuries. So not only after a number of months, your elbow is going to feel a little bit more jelly, but any one time you do your maximum force production style, jam, press or skull crusher, you're more likely to risk pulling your tricep or something like that, or pulling your pack, where's if you do it hypertrophy optimization style, after weeks and weeks and months and months, your joints probably feel better, and any one rep is unlikely to injure you as much compared to that optimized strength feel. In addition to that, strength training, because it requires massive psychological activation and neural drive, because it's physically lifting as much weight as possible, it's going to lower your systemic maximum recoverable volume, because every single rep of strength training beats the shit out of you more. There's only so many reps and sets you can do until your body's like, I can't do this shit anymore, especially in nervous systems, like, I can't, I don't even want to come in here and do this. Whereas if you do hypertrophy style training, you can literally recover from more reps and more sets so you can pour more training down that funnel of growth and get more out of it. If you follow that hypertrophy technique and my muscle connection, maximum range of motion for the target muscle, deep stretch for the target muscle, maximum tension and burn for that movement path, and making that movement path the most difficult for that target muscle, then you end up reducing chronic wear and tear for the same growth, reducing acute injury risk for the same growth, and you can maximize your recoverable training volume, which means that you get more growth with all of those other bad things being minimized, and you're also in a bonus way able to focus on muscles that really you're not connecting with the tongue, because if you're trying to do rear delts, and you're like, I don't know man, stuff's just moving back there and you're doing them for strength, like it's got to get the 20s for set of eight. You're going to get some good rear delts growth, but if you really lens in in your mind's eye on that rear delts going through that big arc, tension in the rear delts, and a burn in the rear delts, then all of a sudden you might connect with your rear delts better and over time see more growth in a muscle that otherwise was not so great. So not only does hypertrophy specific technique maximize growth overall, it can let you target muscles that otherwise would just kind of be skipped over and not get as much of a stimulus.
