That's not a good thing Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for RP strength and you might have heard before that doing compounds first before Isolations and your lifting is better for results, but is that true? Let's find out Do you probably heard before Things like you got to do squats before leg extensions or leg press's compound movement multi joint first Isolation later you got to do pull ups before straight arm lat pull down You got to do dips before you do try set push downs no doubt many of you have heard this a ton But is this practice worthwhile? We have four questions to answer today and we'll answer all four of them question number one is Why is this advice given out like why do people say this kind of stuff is there any merit to it? Question number two how in what circumstances can this advice of compounds before isolation be true? Question number three how can this advice misapplied lead you a straight? Is it ever not true and why and then lastly number four a very super quick guide to making the best Exercise selection choices and strength physique and General lifting for overall physique and health outcomes Let's talk about it. So number one. Why is this advice given out? One reason is that it started being given out a long time ago and So many people said it that everyone just kind of assumed it was received wisdom like Mother's has just what you do and most people just don't question it that doesn't mean it's Completely baseless in fact. It's based on a few really really good ideas If This advice is a good idea. It is a good idea for a few different reasons It is correct if you want to lift as much weight and as many reps with that weight in a compound movement as possible So if you do isolation's first you'll limit your performance on the compound either you have to lift less weight and the same reps or You can lift the same weight, but you have to get fewer reps If you need to demonstrate and train maximum coordination and speed and athleticism During a lift it had better be compound and it had better be early or first in the workout We'll talk about why in just a second and If you are trying to train athletes to be better at sports with weights or you're trying to do overall Strength training making a person stronger Then this advice of compounds first isolation's Isherylations isolation's later is generally really good advice Specifically Here's how the logic works if you are trying to get a strong as possible overall Compound movements are king Multiple muscles are used to the same time just like in real world strength feats in Real world strength you generally try to summon a lot of muscle to do a specific task like pushing or pulling or lifting something One muscle at a time is kind of weird strength training and so compounds win Because you can use more weight because it's more real world for strength because it transfers better to all kinds of other Move performance and because you're using multiple muscles and joints Summing up how much force you're producing total which means you're actually just stronger the more compound and exercise is you can deadlift a whole lot more than you can curl So if you're trying to get a strong as possible overall compounds really are king If you see someone who's like I'm in the gym for strength, they're just one arm curling all the time You're like what you're doing if they're doing close group benches that makes a lot more sense Now if you are trying to get Stronger on a specific compound lift like I'm trying to get my squat going or my deadlift for my bench press or my overhead press or my pull ups The ability to have much of your training for that lift get you maximum weight and maximum reps for whatever target Rage of weight and reps you're doing is critical That's gonna make you stronger. Let me put this into perspective If you are trying to squat 350 pounds three plates on a side for the first time in your life and you are trying to 125 pounds for reps after leg presses after leg extensions You're just not getting any more close to the amount of weight on your back 315 That you would need to in order to train the balance and coordination at such heavy loads The integration of muscles at such heavy loads the nervous system at such heavy loads You would be met at much better off training something like 275 2 300 pounds four reps, but for that you would have to be fresh So if you're very serious about squatting 350 pounds for a single I want to see you hit 250 to 75 300 pounds for reps fresh That's a much better way of training to squat 315 Then if you do all your squats the same way but tired after isolations than it's to 25 on the bar It's 195 pounds on the bar it's to a five on the bar There's gonna be some transfer. It's gonna still make you stronger But not as much as doing it fresh So if your goal is strength maximum strength improvement Yeah, you got to do compounds the ones you're being tested on fresh as much as possible If you do isolations first both your maximum reps and or your weight are impossible and Thus compounds first are a great idea for maximum strength overall and for specific compound lifts Almost overall maximum strength you want compounds first and if you really care about increasing your bench press You should be doing a lot of lifting where bench presses first facts now for athletic coordination using lifting to make athletes stronger at sports If for example, using squats for improving your jump height Isolations slow you down after you fatigue your softly isolations your slower on the compound lifts your rate of force development is lower and the way you're activating your body to jump or to push your to pull Has to take into account that one of the muscles let's say your quads from leg extensions is now fatigued That changes the nervous system's way of activating all the muscles to get you to jump or to get you to push a slide as hard as possible For sports stuff Thus it's teaching you with a body that's kind of weirdly tired in one way and so the amount of transfer of training you would get from doing After isolations squat jumps versus fresh squat jumps is just much lower And so if you're interested in maximum carryover of athletic performance Compounds are really big deal first not second not third so you keep being your isolations to the end if you're training for strength If you're training for specifically some strength on a lift compounds versus really good and then also if you're training for athletic performance And so for now, man, sure shit seems like compounds before isolations is kind of a really good thing However, this is where we get to point number three How the advice of always do compounds before isolations can lead you astray in physique training training to get jacked There are two main kings two variables you have to attend to to get your best results Specificity and SFR stimulus to fatigue ratio Specificity just basically means targeting specific muscles with the most stimulus that they can grow Like if you need bigger biceps you should be training your biceps a lot Our compound lifts the best for biceps some might be pretty good, but maybe there's not the direct answer to that question specificity matters And stimulus to fatigue ratio means maximizing how much growth Stimulus you get how much the muscles will grow after training, but minimizing things like joint and connective tissue stress and Psychological disruption and axial back fatigue and all so stuff So keeping your fatigue lower, but your stimulus higher if in high-perchurfied training We can get Excellence specificity and the highest stimulus to fatigue ratio is possible We don't care if it's isolations first or compounds first that let us do that And if it happens to be isolations first that let us maximize Specificity and maximize stimulus to fatigue ratio We get a lot out of the exercise by paying a small fatigue cost Then that's the correct way to do it and the rule of compounds first before isolations no longer applies for us Now sometimes for physique training compounds first is great advice Especially when the compound is limited by the target muscle and has a great stimulus to fatigue ratio for example If you're doing incline dumbbell pressos, that's a compound movement. Let's say you're doing it first If incline dumbbell presses fail because of your chest and Stimulate your chest like crazy and They don't really beat up your shoulders at elbows much you love the exercise. It's not super fatiguing That means it's amazing on specificity amazing on stimulus to fatigue ratio and then you can absolutely do it first compounds Before isolations later, may you maybe you'll do some flies. So in that case, that's totally cool Now this also has benefits because luckily you have a good stimulus to fatigue ratio Specific exercise as a compound that means it's going to come in and bring a high muscle activity Like compounds can do because of their stability and the weight used Your faster twitch motor units are gonna turn on because of the stability and the heavy weight and that's gonna be really really good stuff But If your compound exercise of choice is Limited by other muscles then the ones you're targeting for growth from that compound exercise and if it's stimulus to fatigue ratio fresh and raw and heavy isn't ideal Then isolation first can be better for example If your lower back is the limiting factor in your barbell squat and And you're strong strong enough that you're squatting a lot and those heavy squats are really starting to beat you up They take a toll familiar lower back from your hips from your knees Systemically they make you get crazy out of breath the super crushing weights psychologically drains you and even if squats don't be you up A ton a ton but like they beat you up some and they're already kind of kicking the dead horse that is your body Because you've done dead lifts early on the week and overhead presses and rows and now you're entire core Your back your posterior chain is so fried that like heavy squats on top of that is just like oh man I'm never gonna recover from next week If that's the thing Doing leg extensions or leg presses isolation stuff first before squats can help How the leg extensions or leg presses maximize Specificity in the quads by directly training quads when the fresh no debate right? Wait wait, no, no. Kiko's not a myth and the idea that it's a myth is BSL safe swearing for the end of this. So the idea that calories in calories out is a myth is promulgated and propagated by various folks in the fitness industry. And it turns out that it's not a myth. So let's get into the realities. First, calories in calories out is essentially covered in the mass energy conservation principle, aka the first law of thermodynamics. And that first law of thermodynamics to my virgin eyes, perusing the literature, has yet to be broken ever in any system, definitely in a biological system and in all studied systems so far. It just seems to be never ever broke. But a lot of people say what it doesn't apply in biological systems and they're wrong. But how did we get this wrong? It turns out it's pretty tempting to get this wrong because of a couple of, oh, elucary things that can occur. Here are a few of them. First, when people say look, I know Kiko is real, calories in calories out, Kiko. Kiko, it's like guy co except no gecko or you eat the gecko. Of accounting for diet and activity and they're just really bad at tracking. So they'll think they eat something when reality they forgot it was this much versus that much. They miss measured. They say they did 30 minutes of cardio, but they reduced their daily walking and they didn't even measure that. So because they mistreated it, they say, hey, look, you know, typical thing I'll see on social media is someone will be like, look, I've been in a surplus, but I'm not gaining. How do you know you're a surplus? A assumption, assumption, assumption, incorrect three assumptions, they're not a really a surplus. So that's definitely a thing that happens. Next, people assume a stable metabolic rate when that rate can actually change. For example, if you are low on thyroid hormones, they can look like calories in calories out. Doesn't work. Except the calories out part is way down because your thyroid stopped working. And when you get on thyroid medication, all of a sudden, calories out works again. It was never the calories in calories out. It was the problem. It was the fact that your hormonal systems were no longer pushing up that calories out part of the equation. You, you want huge delts, which you keep doing the same terrible exercises that a lot of other people are doing for delts, that at the best case scenario, just aren't ideal in the worst case, you're just a damn waste of time. We're going to show you what they are, make sure you're not doing them, and show you how to either modify them, or use entirely different exercises that are way better, so you can finally have freaky delts, and get the attention you need. Let's go get big delts. The standing barbell shoulder press is an amazing shoulder exercise, especially for your front delts, and even a little bit for your side delts. But it is often bastardized in a terrible way, with people doing a push press version of it, which requires leg drive, which is a thing inherently wrong with that just makes you use more weight for the same exact shoulder scenario, and people half-wrap it in that middle range. Really just kind of peel it out of a power rack and do some moving around and call it their shoulder press PR. It's cool for vibes and lets you use a lot of weight, but there are way, way better ways to still do a standing shoulder press and get way more out of it for delgrow. Instead of doing all that wacky stuff using leg drive like crazy in a rear partial range of motion, conventional standing barbell shoulder presses are really intense, touching all the way down to your clavicles, keeping the bar very close to your face as you pull your chin back, and as soon as the bar crosses over your forehead, push your forehead in your entire body forward, lock the weight out up and behind you that engages the side delts a little bit, and allows you to lift the most weight in a very well organized manner that minimizes injuries, maximizes hypertrophy. After you've done your set of that, if you so choose, you can add a superset on top with a few push presses using leg drive to take your shoulders even further beyond failure, then they typically would go. That combo right there is absolutely better than using a ton of weight with a real crap range of motion, she also can feel good about yourself temporarily and trust me. Take it for me a person who's never felt good about themselves, it's overrated. That's just sad at this point. This is just a workout, it's warfare, the weights don't care how heavy they feel, and the moment you want to quit is a moment the real war begins. The one arm at a time, swinging, front raise with dumbbells, is a goaded exercise for looking like you train. It's supposed to hit the shoulders, but it really only hits the front delt, and it doesn't hit the front delt on the stretch position, a ton and hits it in the most contracted position. Also, the swinging makes the reps and strength hard to track, and encourages you to use other muscles of the body and thus enhance systemic fatigue for basically no reason. The cool thing is though, it's a really fun movement to do because you get to swing around a lot, you get to pretend you're your favorite 1990s pro bodybuilder, and look in the mirror while your videographer pans around in grainy 1994 style video. This is not a movement that is remotely efficient and not the most effective movement to make your front delts bigger. There are movements that are similar that are still front raises that can make your front delts absolutely bigger and even hit your side delts as well. Instead of doing the one arm at a time swinging front dumbbell raise, what you can do is get on an incline bench and do dumbbells. With essentially your pinkies pointed up as high as you can, you can still go out to the front. Largely hits your front delt at a time, but it puts a lot more emphasis on the stretch position which grows more muscle. It's two arms at a time so it saves you a bunch of time and because your pointed up pinkies up, it actually recruits your side delts a ton more and remember side delts are the parts of your delts that give you that bubbly look and make you look wider in shape. Front delts don't have that effect on your physique. So that exercise is superior to the swing front one at a time dumbbell raise and almost every respect except one. It absolutely fails the vibe test of being hardcore-pilled and 90s bodybuilder goded. Some things you're just going to have to trade off for getting bigger delts. Okay, not the ideal shoulder move is a standing dumbbell internal and external rotation. Why is this bad? Because you see gravity only points up and down, not side to side, not front to back. So when you are doing internal and external shoulder rotations to warm up, all those structures and the shoulders, that's a good thing. And that's totally fine to do especially if you have a history of shoulder joint injury. But if you're doing it standing up, which like half the people of the gym seem to do, literally applies nominal forces to the shoulder. Stop doing it. Here's what to do instead. Instead of standing for internal and external rotations, you can lie down on a bench or you can do it with cables. In that case you get all of the benefits of this awesome shoulder warm up. But literally you get the benefits because the forces actually apply to where they're supposed to go. Instead of you standing there and pretending to do internal external rotations against force, but really you're just holding a dumbbell that's only difficult to hold up and down and not in internal and external rotation directions that you want to apply the forces. So on a cable or lying down on a bench, this is totally good to go and absolutely my recommendation. Guys, for a lot of this shoulder training, what ends up happening is three mistakes are made. Maybe it mistakes are a little bit of an exaggeration for some of these, but tendencies that make shoulder training not nearly as ideal. Let me talk about all three and how you can obviate them. The first mistake that's made is oftentimes cutting the range of motion substantially and cutting it away from the deep stretch, when which training is most productive for hypertrophy. So instead of doing mid range of motion shoulder press stuff, try to think about getting as deep of a stretch as you can in every single movement, especially ones with a forces aligned and then you're really really good to go. That is a big fix that'll let you use less weight, save your joints, and make you even more jack. Another problem is a lot of folks will use movements and use them in some ways that involve other muscles and other motions that don't really have much to do with the shoulder without really any enhance. The one arm at a time front raise that we're doing, yeah sure it involves the shoulders plenty of the front delts really, but what ends up happening is you end up swinging your body around just to use more weight. If you just sat down or stood stationary and did two arms at the same time, you would use less momentum, use less weight, accumulate less fatigue, and get all the benefits with just the same. A lot of times this happens in the shoulder press which turns into a push press with leg drive, nothing wrong with a dedicated planned push press, but if you call your push press the shoulder press instead and pretend that it's the same thing, you're going to be in for a lot of fatigue accumulation and using wave of your loads that you ever have to have never shot a big load in my life. I've shot plenty of small ones. The other mistake that people tend to make in many cases of shoulder training is to mistake front deltraining for shoulder training. Remember, the side delts get a lot of work from almost nothing that you do for upper body, while the rear delts get a ton of work through every single back movement that you do, and the front delts get amazing work for every single chest movement that you do that requires pressing of any kind. Side delts also visually stick out to your sides, and I know that sounds crazy, but it really is true. And so if you want that nasty Jared feather, IFBB pro or max drasny, the editor boy, the IFBB, the great IFBB bro, kind of side delt vibe, you're going to want bigger side delts. That's what gives you width. The thing is a lot of pressing, a lot of front raises are cool, they're fun, you can use a lot of weight, but it really doesn't hit your side delt, nearly as much as varieties of lateral raises, be they with cables, be they with dumbbells, or whatever else in implement you're using. The reality of shoulder training to get bigger shoulders, especially ones that give you that awesome look, is that you're going to have to train your side delts a lot, and a lot of times that's not glorious training. And listen, sucks, I know, but that's what gets you bigger shoulders. Give some thought to those sort of mistakes, stay away from making them, and I'll say one more, though this one is a bit more nuanced, a little bonus round. Try to pick movements that are very difficult at that bottom end stretch range of motion. You can potentially even try some exerciseer in which you cross the body with laterals, but you have to do them with cables that doesn't mean lateral raises with dumbbells are a bad thing. But if you have a shoulder exercise like the dumbbell front raise, and you have an exercise alternatively that you can do, that is the cross body side delt lateral raise, especially from a pin that's hip height. Man, that's probably just going to be a better exercise than those cases. If you have to choose, choose the exercises that develop a ton of tension at the bottom, that actually target your side delts, don't use unnecessary muscles and movements, and that make sure to get a nice deep stretch of big range of motion. If you stick to those, there's less glory, but more shoulder size. They really have to ask yourself the question, what's more important? Glorious shoulder size, and that's a trick question, because once you get big enough shoulders, you're just glorious, see you win both. The behind the neck press is often bastardized beyond all recognition, and that's the bad way to do it that I want you to avoid. Going in the mid range, barely coming down at all, using a ton of weight, it really just turns into a f***er exercise in which you try to see how much you can be behind the neck press, which just ends in either nothing, because not much happens to your muscles, or disaster when your shoulders just snap right off of your body. There are better ways to do the behind the neck press, and, in a little preview of what we're going to talk about next, alternative exercises if you can't do that exercise effect. If you're going to do the behind the neck press, try to come all the way down to touch the very bottom part of your neck, pause for a second, and then come all the way back up. This allows awesome hypertrophy from that deep stretch, and is nice and safe, because you're always in control and movement all the time. If you do the behind the neck press more dynamically, you're probably going to be fine, but you could snap your shit up. You will also get in, stay calm. Myofibular versus suckaplasmic hypertrophy. Myofibros are the actual tissue inside the muscle, the organous inside the muscle that how is the contraction machinery acting in myocene and shell like that? Those are myofibros. But then there's other parts of the muscle cell, which all look like muscle on the outside, that have, you know, there's more so it's called suckaplasmic. And it's just like there's some other organous floating around in there. You're nucleus, tectlic, sits in it. There's ribosomes, and vesicles, and stuff. And it's kind of the more poofier, liquidier version. Right? That's at a microscopic scale, though. So it all just looks like muscle at the top end. So are people saying you get more myofibular hypertrophy and less suckaplasmic hypertrophy? That's possible. But we also know for many studies that there is a distinct myofibular and hyper and suckaplasmic hypertrophy. But typically, suckaplasmic hypertrophy occurs first. Like when you first start resistance training, your muscle glycogen, the ability to store goes up much faster initially than the myofibos are constructed and new because they just take longer to construct. But at the end of three or six months of training, doesn't matter what rep range you train in, you roughly have the same ratio of myofibos to suckaplasmic. The two most important things in this world if you're keeping track. Here's the deal. Alcohol presents, I think at least four problems for muscle and strength gains. Problem number one is that it interferes with recovery. Alcohol consumption, especially at the high rates, increases the systemic fatigue that you experience. And it prevents the systemic fatigue that you create and you're training from falling off as fast between sessions, between weeks. So instead of you training for a few weeks in your fatigue climbing like this, if you consistently consume higher and higher amounts of alcohol, your fatigue climbs faster. You may just be scraping by, hitting smaller PRs or even tanking and not hitting NAPRs at all. So it's definitely a thing that absolutely happens. Hey folks, Dr. Mike, your Renaissance Pyrrization. I have three squat tips for you to potentially instantly improve your squat by a mile. How do I learn about these three tips? Well, Jared Feather, I, Phoebe Pro, and myself, were at the Arnold this past year. The Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic, Expo, and Bodybuilding Show. And we had a booth set up for Renaissance Pyrrization where we would have a barbell and a rack and we would critique your technique and a ton of people took us up on this and they were all super awesome. While coaching folks, we were prepared to use 80 trillion cues and corrections that we know from being in this three years and have always degrees and stuff. But we ended up only using like 10 and then maybe 80 or 90 percent of the time, we actually only used three. These cues are so effective and the mistakes that lead to them needing to be used are so common and so easily rectified by these cues. I had to make a video to share this with you guys so that you can try this both in your own training. If you have problems with squat technique and also in training your own clients because I know what ton of you guys train clients and help other people maybe even just your parents or your siblings and try to get them to lift weights and a lot of times your squat may look great. But then you work with someone else and you look at their technique and you're like, I don't even know where to begin with you. You're doing everything wrong. Do I have to really manually from scratch? Mind meld with you and show you how to squat? Quite because these three tips could hack it. So here we go. Shut up. Let's get the three tips going. First, almost everyone who starts squatting has not positioned their toes out enough. That means any stance they take. Generally widening the stance by a little seems to work, but that's not even the important thing. You take their toes and you rotate them out much closer to the 45 degree line than you would. The 90 degree line or zero degree line. 45 degrees is where you want on average and for a lot of people that will feel a little strange because that's not typically how you're running or how you jump, but it sure a shit is how you squat. In addition to point two, because we have a rule in squatting, your knees generally track with your toes. If you have someone point their toes out, that's rule one. Rule one sub two, still rule one, is make sure that their knees come out and generally speaking, that means as they descend lower and lower, their knees come out. Further and further, they're pushing the knees to outside of their body. That aligns the ankles to the knees to the hips and all of a sudden it can allow you to get way greater depth without having to come up on your toes or sink back and round your back. And all of a sudden, you're like, whoa, it's much easier to squat and I can get through the squatting motion way better. So that's tip number one and it's a huge deal. Squatting without it is kind of a non-starter. Tip number two. Especially when coaching someone, not just doing the lift once you've learned it, but in teaching the lift to do it properly, having someone descend slowly and consider a pause at the bottom of the movement is a huge teaching tool. The reason is this. Keeping your knees pushed out is something you have to focus on when you're squatting and trying to change your technique for the better. If you drop down fast, a lot of times you just rebound right off your tendons and come back up and fucking who knows what your knees did. But if you go down slow as you descend, you both get a better feel for where your body isn't space and can correct it on the fly and it gives you time to implement the knees out, so as you're descending, you're thinking, he's out and he's out and he's out and he's out and he's out and because you're descending slowly, you could actually implement the cue instead of being like, you go down and come up. Oh fuck, I forgot to push my knees out. Like I said, just a second ago, as you descend, you can focus on having your weight spread over me, spread evenly on your toes and heels. If you go down really quick, we saw a lot of this happen at the Arnold people drop in and drop out and we're like, I can't even give you any technique, because you're in and out too fast. And they would usually cut the range of motion by a ton because as soon as they feel that springiness, they come back up. If you go down slow and you pause it wherever you think the bottom is, you're in a really good position. Then wherever's coach you can say, okay, that looks good. Come back up, you come back on. They say, okay, down slow knees out, knees out, knees out, knees out and as you get lower and you think you're going to stop, they go, hey, go go deeper, deeper, deeper, you're at the very, what you think is bottom, they're like, okay, pause, hold it as you hold that pause. Your body is awareness mechanisms, proprioception where your body is in space, recalibrate, recalibrate, recalibrate. Your body is a rapidly learning neural network system. Your brain is anyway in your spinal cord and peripheral nerves. So as you are in that position, because you didn't get into an out of it really quick, you can replicate it better. Every second, every micro-secret you spend in the descent and every second you spend at the bottom position, which is the most challenging, is neural learning happening. Your brain is learning, oh, this is where my bot needs to be. This is where my knees need to be. This is where my hips are, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. So if you practice slow, which by the way, in every single technique, they teach you in every other sport, you practice to slow. You're learning a tennis forehand. First, you go slow. Backhand, slow, eventually faster, faster, faster, but if you're practicing good squatting technique and you're just dropping in, slow the fuck down, sit at the bottom. And every time you get lower and lower in the bottom, you sit there for a second or two. It begins as a very uncomfortable alien feeling. After five or six reps, you're like, hey, I'm fine. Then a groove down here. I don't love it down here. Nobody does, but she feels really like it's a place I know. Lastly, tip number three comes in especially at this juncture. Your knees and toes are already in alignment. You're already squatting back and down nice and slowly. At this point, there is a tendency to either come forward on your toes, or if you sit back on your heels to round your back and cave over in your chest, you're not trying to sit down in the squat. I can't tell you, fucking, politically and correct time. It's not so politically and correct. Fuck, I don't wanna say it anyway. Anytime, people send me memes or gifts of babies that are squatting. And they're like, hey, look at how natural of a squatter of this baby is. They're fucking wrong because the baby never has a fucking elevated chest. And they're lower back as in tight. Your baby's rounding. It's fucking back. The shit squat. Oh great, he's got his heels on his toes on the ground. You could do that too if you fucking round your back enough. No, look, I don't think babies should be brought up to a standard of high level squatting. They're just babies. It's adorable when you do anything. You are not a fucking baby. I assume. If you're a baby watch on this channel, hello. And when your pretty natural intelligence is welcomed here, don't kill us all when you ascend to the next level. In any case, if you're not a baby, you can do one better. As you are opening up your knees, toes pointed out, descending slowly, you're gonna get to a point in your squat where it's harder to descend. Everything starts to bind up and your chest is naturally gonna cave in. This is where you use the cue of chest up. If you are attending to do a low bar squat, if you have a, if you are prone to extreme Lordosis, very arched sway back at the bottom. And if you want to produce as much force as possible for a one repetition maximum, do not put your chest up. Do the ribs down, shit, like Chris stuff and says. If you want to do the proper hypertrophy, bodybuilding squat, or even a weightlifting squat, it's the same squat almost. Your chest stays up. So as you point your toes out, knees come out. You go down slow, keep your chest up the entire tightness, especially at the bottom, look forward and or up. And then at some point when you stop, you're gonna be a real close to hitting full depth. Little practice worms like that, slow slow slow, put a little weight on the bar slow slow slow. Maximum depth, knees out, big chest. You're gonna be hitting what is almost the perfect squat. It took Jared and I, an average of two minutes per person to take their squat from, well, a lot of people had great squats and we were just gonna get the fuck out of here. You don't need us for anything, shake your hand, pick your, get out. But a lot of folks, just a few people I guess, had squats that started out like, um, dumpster fire, giant disaster. And no offense when I started squatting as the worst in the world, in just with these three cues over like two minutes, we were able to take most people and have them just really squat very competently. So if you're coaching other people or even if you're coaching yourself, get the toes out, get the knees out, descend slowly, take a pause at the bottom of each position that you think is the lowest. And when the bottom is close, keep your chest up. And I think your squats are gonna improve and if I'm wrong, she, she, wouldn't be the first thousandth time. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pairization, and today's BS topic is the idea that weight training is bad for weight loss. You will hear this a relatively often by the female sex. And I quote that sounds something like this. When I like lift weights, I get like a pretty big. How's that for vocal fry? Boom. And here's the thing, there's not a situation where that's not totally raw. It's got a little tiny bit of truth to it, which is much how this BS really starts. When many people start training with weights, their muscles take unmuscle damage and begin the growth and repair process. And that leads to a situation called tonus of the muscles, which is when a bunch of different stuff would mostly water enters the muscle itself. And that intramuscular water expands the muscle and can even jack up your body weight in just a few days of weight training about five pounds more than it normally is. But that makes you look more jacked and shapely and it's no way adding any body fat at all. But it's a very good way to make it look more muscular right away by a very, very small margin. Anyway, you gain beyond that initial five pounds of intramuscular bloat is just because you're in a caloric surplus, which happens to some people automatically when they start resistance training or training with weights because some people in the start training with weights to get extra hungry. They eat more food, they gain weight, much of that weight is muscle, but if they really go to tonus eating food, they can gain even some fat. Then weight training absolutely prevents them from losing weight and can cause weight gain and it's no good. And I'm just like, man, I don't want to fuck that guy. That's a real world strong ass human being. However, it's a very different question than what it does for dealt size. So let's take a look. Just from a real first level analysis, dealt training via the overhead press has a couple of features. First, it trains due to angle of push. The front delts significantly more than any other exercise. And better than any other exercise. So if you want unreal front delth hypertrophy, the overhead barbell press is a very good place to start. Now, when people say delts, they don't usually just mean front delts. They mean side delts and rear delts. And the side delts get trained somewhat, generally overhead press, but other exercises like G, even upright rows and all kinds of laterals, even front raises, engage your side delts more than overhead presses. A, even unross stimulus magnitude, the amount of shear stimulus for get about fatigue, usually is better for side delts in like 10 other exercises that overhead press. If you consider the overhead press overall dealt growth, yeah, you write about front delts, maybe not so right about side delts. On the stimulus to fatigue ratio, because especially standing barbell presses create so much spinal loading and so much requisite for stability. The fatigue is really high. And the stimulus to fatigue ratio of almost any other dealt exercises usually better than overhead barbell press. Not great. Now, third point is the worst. People say, I need big delts. I'm going to do overhead press. It basically doesn't train the rear delts at all. So saying, hey, I've got delts. I'm going to train delts. Here's a delt exercise overhead press. We didn't think of overhead press for delt hypertrophy. You know, it's not the best way to phrase that question, because for overall dead hypertrophy, the overhead press is just not that great. It trains the front delts very well, but everything else, ma'am. So just to frame that. Last two slides. We're going to go through a question and answer system of reasons that you could train the overhead press and reasons that you probably shouldn't. So can you still use the overhead press? Lots of your probably panicking right now and going, oh my god, Dr. Mike, but I loved overhead press. Can I still use it? Well, here's the thing. If you want to grow your triceps and front delts, yes, the overhead press is a very good thing to use. If you get a very good side delt pump disruption, so on, etc. From overhead presses, then yes, they're a great exercise even for side delts. If you get a good stimulus to fatigue ratio, so not only the stimulus, good, but the fatigue is a minimal for other presses for all those things. Number one and two, then yes, again, the answer is that it's good to train overhead press. However, standing presses, which is generally what people say when our meme when they say overhead press, because of the axial fatigue, the spinal loading, they are so often highly fatiguing that the stimulus to fatigue ratio is usually not great. What we can fix that. So point number four, yes, you can train the overhead press, especially if you modify the overhead press for a higher stimulus to fatigue ratio for your shoulders. How do you do that first? Do them seated versus standing? I'm not a big fan of seated barbell overhead presses. There's something manly that's removed from the exercise, specifically the standing upright. But as far as stimulus to fatigue ratio, you get much less compressive force traveling through your legs, much less rockers or first ability. If you're seated, you get the same or higher because you're stable, standing with us for the delts seated, but you get less fatigue. So it's usually a better approach. And it's one of the things that is nothing in my heart makes me happy to say that, but that's just the way it is. Next point is keep the load close to your face. If you push the barbell out this way, it's more front-nose triceps, less side-dults, because the side-dults don't work this way. The side-dults keep the bar close to your face, pushing up and back, as soon as you clear your head, push back and out, make sure you're seated in a position that which you don't fall backwards like that. And then you will hit your side-dults better. Your traps better. It's not just all front-dults. That's very good. And the last thing is given that you're already overhead pressing, giving it you're doing an attack in the ec which stimulates the side-dults more. The first thing I see many people do wrong is training volume. Look, low volume protocols work fine, but if your chest isn't growing, hitting it with more training volume is the way to go. The card literature has still to find the limit to how much volume you can do for muscle growth and doing more will likely benefit your chest. Bonus, a very recent meta regression showed that even up to 11 fractional sets per muscle growth per session will still keep you growing. So if chest is one of these lagging body parts for you, hitting it with 20 or even 30 sets per week, is a good educated bet. When it comes to your session training volume, you don't want to do everything in one session. So when I say 20 to 30 sets, ideally split those into two to three sessions, so you can get high quality sets very close to failure. Hey folks, doctor Mike here for Assam's Pyrritation. And today's BS video is about how to learn to burn fat for fuel. Aaaaah, aaah, aaah, aaah, aaah, aaah! The like that, but with fat. Let's get into it. The claim generally sounds something like this. When you go low-carb, your body learns to burn fat as fuel, brother. You always see brother, why do they say that? It sounds sweet, but there's a problem. Yes, it's definitely true that you can learn to burn fat for fuel in high intensity exercise. The problem is, by the design of the system and your body that burns anything for fuel, that is not the ideal fuel source for high intensity exercise, and you know what is the great evil, the eye of sarnet's self carbs. I just had a vision of the eye of sarnet from one of the rings, it was like a Cheerio. Mine's fine, trash. You're at a low carb diet, and I'm saying, and that shit goes, zap, and you're like, you're like, you're like, crawl over to the ice cream and someone's like, no, Frodo, don't stop going keto. Samwise, Samwise doesn't help you, right? Cause if we didn't get a bunch of like, lambness, bread, or whatever, well the fuck are we trying to get jacked out here and get ketoed up? All carb diet, you know, they works out it, right? And they might have meat. In any case, here's the thing. Anything faster than a very slow jog relies predominantly on carbohydrate for fuel. So when people say you want to learn, to burn fat as fuel, they usually specifically refer to really intense exercise. And that's just not a great idea. Can you learn to do it? Yes, your body actually does get a little bit better of burning fat for fuel, even in high intensity exercise if you expose it to, you know, whatever protein kept equal higher fat, lower carb diet, especially if it's almost zero carb. Yes, absolutely your body gets better at it. But the analogy there is like, you absolutely can redesign a race car, modify a race car to burn like 87 gasoline, normal ass gasoline or petrol if you're from the rest of the world. And it will run with regular gasoline, and it won't gunk up the engine, but it'll run shitier because racing fuel is better because it's optimized to make you go faster. That's why the fucking's racing fuel. So if you're eating lots of fats and very little carbs, you try to get your body to get really good at burning fats for fuel, you are redesigning your race car to burn regular gasoline and losing races all the fucking time. Now, what if we're talking about fat loss? It turns out that if you reduce any kinds of calories, you burn about the same amount of total calories off. And unless you're reducing protein, don't do that that's stupid. So whether you're using carbs or fat, you are burning almost exclusively body fat if you wait trained and have a decent lock in on your diet. Multiple high protein Phoenix per day, regular weight training, a calorie deficit of either carbs or fats burns predominantly fats, plain and simple, and you don't have to eat exclusively fats, and there's not enhanced your ability to burn fat. And another thing is your body is a fat-bring machine and exercise cool, but exercise burns a very small fraction of your total calories per day and gets you not so lean. Most of your calories per day are burned in just normal activities and a huge fraction during sleep. You're not even exercising that. So you don't have to turn into a fat-bring machine. You just have to create a small daily deficit, keep your physical activity in check. Eat plenty of protein, lift weights, and it doesn't really matter if most of your calories come from mostly carbs, mostly fats, or anywhere in between, you burn pretty much the same amount of fat and get the same level of lean. Period. Except if you do it with more carbs and fewer fats, you generally tend to keep more here muscle on your body, have better training, and feel better for most people. Some people love low carb diet, no judgment, but it's certainly very difficult to say, listen, go low carb, teach your bite and burn fat, and you'll have better results, because you straight up won't in most cases. So yes, you can adapt to burn fat easier during exercise. But that's not, and that positive adaptation, unless you regularly have to compete on low carb hydrates, which is nonsense, because in competition, you bring any kind of food you want with you, if you want, on a bike, for example, or an ultra run. And at the end of the day, eating low carb is a high performer when you have access to carbs, and could be an even better performer, is, Scott's very very committed, and run all time, going. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Periodization, and I'm hitting you with another hypertrophy myth. And the myth today is that training must has to foreshore be ultra hard if you're serious about growth. We'll talk about what this myth really is and what people are saying. We'll talk about the sort of silver lining that maybe it does make some good points. Talk about the bad stuff in ways in which it really is a myth and it will sort of wrap it all up by talking about a little real talk of what you should take away from a video like this. The idea is that training has to be super hard for your grow and or just grow at your best and any training that doesn't push the limits is suboptimal. And you'll see this in a whole lot of social media comments of like, oh, he didn't look like he was that close to failure or like these guys don't scream. And then you get embellished. The social media content, we're bodybuilders yell after every rap of like extensions and stuff like that and hashtag hardcore and triple drop sets and all this other stuff. And every session we go to war and every session, everything is the failure all the time because that's how you get results. And if you don't get results trying like that, your results aren't the best or you're not serious. Okay, that's an interesting idea. The silver lining here is that for intermediates and for advanced trainees on occasion testing the limits is a very good idea. We know scientifically that the best growth occurs just before the limits. Three, two, one reps in reserve, one three or two or one reps away from muscular failure. But going to one and then zero reps away from failure and two failure itself on occasion, the one, seven, mesocycle at the very end is a good way to make sure that what you think is three, two or one reps away from failure actually is because you could be said guessing it could be kidding yourself. What you think is three reps away from failure is really six, which is not so uncommon. So occasionally pushing and is a good idea, at least for that reason. Occasionally pushing it, it also have some unique growth benefits. We're really pushing it to your limits and a little beyond your normal limits can maybe cause a type of growth, maybe via satellite cell recruitment that is special and is qualitatively different type of growth that you just would never get training normally. That's speculative, but the speculation is reasonable enough for us to at least consider, you know, we're not 100% sure that training with two hour all the time is the best gains. To make a occasion we could really really push it to see if we can get any of that kind of growth, right? And for folks that do this, the last week or weeks of a program often the last week or the last two or just kind of be brutal, especially that last week, everything is one or zero reps away from failure and it's just like, you're going to metaphorical war at that point. Lots of screaming, lots of crying, lots of laying in a puddle of your own sweat, make it a sweat, angel in the gym. That's a thing that has to happen. I get to, it gets flagged from all sides when you're in social media and you're a big deal celebrity like me. You get crisis from both sides, so one of the things we get in our YouTube videos, you know, every Monday will show a training video. And one of the things is we say, like, hey, like, don't train like this all the time, this is towards the end of a mesocycle, usually you know, we train at some more ups and reserve than this and it's not all triple drops that's to failure. People will say, you know, this is really too much and there's an affordable guy that comes in as Ken and Nadi recover from this, like shut up, everyone's clapping at these Nadi. Thank you, clap them out, get out of here. And people seem to think like any time you train hard or you're doing something wrong, you're going to kill yourself. So the good part of this train hard idea is that it normalizes the idea that at least sometimes you should be training hard, that's okay. I get a lot of flack for throwing up after leg workouts and the, you know, is that something you want to do every leg workout? No, and I don't do it every leg workout, but I'll do it every now and again because I just have to throw up because I'm going that hard and there's nothing wrong with that on vacation. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Renaissance Pre-Dization. And today's video is about the three pieces of gym gear that advanced bodybuilders have to have, of course, that's a clickbait title. But three pieces of gym gear that I think have huge benefits for advanced bodybuilding. And please make all the inside gear jokes you like in the comments. And boost the algorithm. Here's the deal. First, what is an advanced bodybuilder? It is somebody in my view, the best definition for this I've been able to come up with. Is somebody for whom the basics executed normally, no longer cause reliable gains, for whom even some insights like, oh, I have to start dealing with the start following program, they no longer produce reliable gains. This individual has to have training as well as possible. In order for any gains to be even highly probabilistic, otherwise the default is no gains at all. That's right. You have seen people training for years at your gym. Putting in lots of effort and not seemingly progressing, you could technically call them advanced if they have already done a lot of the basics pretty well, and it's just the nuances they're riding on. Four folks in that situation, nuances matter as far as executing your training. For example, at that point technique has to be personalized, to whatever gives you the best stimulus to fatigue ratio, not somebody else. I got an intermediate, can squat like most people and get decent squat results. An advanced person may have to squat very differently for their own body type, or even a band in squats altogether and search out other better stimulus to fatigue ratio exercise. With nuances like that, it also makes sense that some gym gear stuff you can buy and take with you and you can get a lot of benefits. You can also start to make advantages at the advanced level that are difficult to ignore and unwise to kind of relegate to thinking, wow, you could use this stuff, but you don't have to use it. No, no, this stuff really does pay big dividends, especially for the advanced. First thing, first on that list, is the Versa grip. The Versa grip company, they ignored all my calls and emails. I never called or emailed them, but I did talk to them once at the Arnold, and I was like, hey, I have a following, and I want to rep you guys, I don't need any money, just want to be able to say that real cool. And they're like, yeah, we don't do a brand sponsorship for athletes. Okay, you guys are cool. Anyway, oh look, a train I have to catch, and I ran under the train and committed suicide. So that didn't go so well, but so this is not any kind of sales pitch. I make nothing off of this or anything else real here. Versa grips, Versa grips essentially are the modern version of a lifting strap, and they are categorically better and almost every way. They're all pretty close to magic. If you wrap the Versa grip handle around something and put your hand on top of it, there's a very good chance your entire hand will fall off of the bone before that Versa grip breaks or is let go. All right, or let's go. And because of that major advantage, Versa grips can take back training, deadlift training, any training where you have to pull with the arms, especially shoulder training. How do you do laterals with your regular grip is beyond me, if your shoulders have gotten as strong as most people's shoulders, get in relation to their grip. If your back has gotten as big as strong as it usually will in relation to your grip, if your legs get as strong for stiff leg and deadlift and dumbbell lunges, etc., as strong as the normal people's legs get when they're advanced and relation to their grip, because they're grip gets stronger, but the back and the traps, and the legs for sure often waste strong or muscle groups. If that happens, you can no longer use many exercises without grip becoming the predominant limiting factor. When you're training your back, short of like, flat prayers, and a few other things, your grip may be the only thing you are training very hard after a while. If you get Versa grips, of course you can have regular traps or fine chalk is very good, but Versa grips show me that you are interested in the highest level of grip ability and you're just interested in the really shutting off the limiting factor. You can do machine roads, and it's all just down to your back. Amazing, huge dividends. I can't recommend this product more. If you haven't gotten it, and you tell me your advance, then I see your workouts, you better have the strongest fucking grip of all time. Or you just haven't thought things through. Next, weightlifting belt. Any kind of belt is really good. I prefer the pioneer brand belt, because they have so much customization, and they're really high quality, but other belt companies are fine. Some of them are very good, a weightlifting belt, or a lifting belt in general, does not have to be for the sport of weightlifting. A lifting belt allows you to create a high level of intramodinal pressure in your core and glumber region, which allows you to transduce more of a signal to contract, especially your legs during heavy leg training. And what that does is it just leaks out more ability out of your legs. Now as I begin to, as an intermediate, that probably just doesn't matter that much. And your legs and core will be in ratio, relatively strong enough to each other that you have a core, realistically that can outlift your legs and that's never too weak. But your legs get stronger than your core. We know this because almost every powerlifter at the high level, when it is legal to do so, will wear a lifting belt. The reason for that is pretty simple. The core tends to be a weak link, and if you make it stronger via the addition of a belt, notice you're not making the core stronger itself. You're making the whole system of core plus belt stronger. If you use a belt, you can get more out of your legs. And as a hard lifting lifter, if you're doing hacksquats, if you're doing regular squats, if you're doing good mornings, as a high advanced bodybuilder, you probably are interested in putting out a belt, because it will just maximize what you get out of your glutes, your hamstrings, and your quads at the very least. And if you're going to do any kind of dead lifting, it also keeps your back nice and safe, at heavier loads than you would normally be able to use, which is a really, really big deal. It's a big help. Is it mandatory, of course, but does it make the situation better? Where it actually makes your legs get absolutely higher, raw stimulus magnitude training? Yes. Yes, it sure does. Will it make your core weaker to wear a belt? Yes. But only if you wear a belt, and never increase how much weight you're lifting, above what you could have done without a belt. If you can squat to 25 for 10 without a belt, this you put on a belt and squat to 25 for 10. Never go above the 20 or 30 extra pounds of belt can let you lift for the same reps. Then yeah, sure, shit, your core will get weaker the belt will remain, and that it'll be harder to squat to 25 for 10 without a belt in a few weeks. Why the fuck would you do that? You put on the belt so you can go and get stronger in your legs, and now you can squat to 40 with a belt for 10s, to 25 for 10 without a belt. Without a belt, we'll still feel weirder, and for a few weeks you'll be weaker, just because you've learned to use the belt so well. With the underlying strength and size of the core musculature, we'll continue to go up if you use a belt, if you challenge yourself. So if you ever want to take the belt off, you know, feel weird to use it, no belt squats for a while, but then very shortly within several weeks, literally, two or three, you will be as strong as you ever were without a belt. Amazing. Lastly, number three, are weight lifting shoes. These are shoes for the sport of weight lifting. They have a heel and an easy slow ramp, that ends at about three quarters of an inch, to one and a quarter inch typically at the end. In the heel itself, these shoes allow for a huge amount of stability in leg training movements. They allow a ton of friction between whatever it is you're standing on and the shoe itself. And because they have that ramp situation, the actual heel lift, you get two things out of it. One is you can now go much deeper with all sorts of pressing and squatting movements and get your quads at better stimulus. It's so glorious, gorgeous. Big arms are it. However, on our way to the obvious, obviously great goal of getting big arms, which is obvious and amazing, we tend to air in at least five really common ways. I'm going to talk about them, but talk about why they're not such a great idea to do and give you alternatives that are better. So number one, is the myth that you must have an arm day? You must do biceps and triceps together in the same workout. There is no distinct benefit of this. In fact, if your biceps are sufficiently pumped, it actually limits the range of motion on your triceps, which sometimes means they're not getting as much of a stretch and high load stretch, which means actually it's suboptimal. Can you do an arm day? Of course, but it's not an necessity. It's cool vibe, you get a big pump, but I don't actually help you with long-term growth, any more than training arms biceps and triceps separately in their own day. It's tough to program this into the same split, because a lot of times you back and biceps, chest and triceps, but then if you're doing arms, it's also like a dirt. I had biceps, the triceps, you want to know, is it gets confusing? The other problem with this is that there's a discordance and healing time. Triceps tend to be bigger, stronger, more susceptible to stretch under load, and so when you train biceps, you can do 10 sets of biceps and they can soar for a day or two and then you're good to go. You train triceps, they get soar for like two or three days and maybe even four and then you're good to go. So if you're always trying to train them together, you'll have to needlessly constrict the amount of effort, or volume you do for triceps, and needlessly do too much for biceps, it's a weird way to try to make things work. So I got to say, bice and trice together is totally fine, but absolutely not an necessity or a net benefit. If you're doing it for vibes, God bless you. If you have to screw up the rest of your program to keep an arm day in the mix, consider not doing that. Number two, a lot of people will say that for legs, you need to hire reps to grow. That's a 15 to 20, but for arms, sets of 8 to 12 grow best. That is not from my experience a dependably true thing. What that ends up doing in most cases is constraining people to one very small rep range, where for biceps and triceps are a grade 8 to 12. The reality is that in many cases, sets of 5 to 8 can absolutely 100% grow your biceps and triceps really well. So can sets of 8 to 12? So can sets of 12 all the way up to even 30 repetition. So instead of thinking okay, legs, higher reps, arms, lower reps, think of legs and arms as any number of reps between 5 and 30, and there are two things to say about that. One, try to find which rep range works better for your biceps and triceps in that whole huge range. And two understand that any rep range that works best for a while will eventually get stale and then it's a good idea for you to shift the rep range to something higher or something lower, which unjust variation will promote more growth. Don't constrain yourself to one rep range experiment across the board because for you you might find that on average sets of 15 work better for my biceps. So it's a 10 work better for my triceps, but every now and again when that gets stale I flip the script and do them in reverse. Number three, huge problem is a lot of people are not going for deep stretch nearly enough and they're biceps and triceps. People do cable extensions halfway down, they'll do bicep curls and they don't ever get a deep stretch or they'll just do bicep curls standing up and they don't have any tension in the bottom because gravity doesn't point in that direction. Show them a video of lying dumbbell curls and they say that looks lame, but in reality lying dumbbell curls are probably one of the most brutal and effective ways to train your bicep. Precisely because it stretches your bicep under its most maximum load in relation to gravity at that very deep part of the stretch. For triceps, squat crushers, etc. Yes, you'll have to take some lead off the bar, book going all the way down to a squat pressure to stretch your nose or each shin or even your throat if you have a spotter. Hey folks, Dr. Mike here for Anassand's Periodization, and I have five rules for you to follow for your quad training to get the biggest possible legs that you can. These five helpful, hopefully, tips will get your legs bigger, so let's just get to it because you don't have time for videos, you got time to get big legs. First, quadriceps like many other muscles seem to grow best when they are stretched under heavy load, which means that if you're doing depth, squats, hacksquats, leg presses, you want to go deep for a big stretch. Take those squats as far as that range of motion goes until your calves touch your hamstrings or put another way, depth before dishonor. Rule number two, when you're pushing whatever implement be it a regular squat, hacksquat, leg press, pendulum squat, Smith machine squat, I can continue, but I won't. Make sure that you're pushing your weight through your heels as well as your toes. If you're just on your tippy toes, those are 60 squats, they can be effective, but in most cases, you want to produce as much force as possible, recruiting the big, strong, narrowly motor units in your quads to get as jacked as possible, which means force through your heels and through your toes at the same time and even foot dispersion of force. Rule number three is as you descend in squats, Smith machine squats, leg presses, etc. You name it, you want to, in most cases, to have your knees come way over your toes at the bottom. First, in a squat, you sit back and down, but then as soon as you've tilted your hips and broken through, you want to make sure that you sit straight down, letting your knees come forward while your heels stay on the ground or on the platform that you're using. As your quads are involved in that forward knee movement, they are going to be stretched a ton on her load, put into a very mechanically disadventageous position from which they will have to work super hard and thus get tons of growth. And the big benefit is you don't even have to use that much external weight. If you know how to squat properly, a hundred pounds less than you used to squat for reps can zap your quads better than that hundred pounds more ever could. Rule number four is to match the repetition range you use to the exercise type that you're using it. Here's an example of things that work for most people. Definitely feel free to be creative, and if this doesn't work for you, adjust it to your own needs, but here we go. That's a five to ten are probably best for squats, why? Because squats are conducive to lifting really heavy. And also, there are such a whole body movement and involve a lot of your anti-gravity muscles for balance and coordination that they take a ton of metabolic drive and they generate a ton of systemic and cardiovascular fatigue. So if you're doing many more than 10 repetitions a lot of times you're breathing becomes limiting factor and the last several reps just aren't quality and won't stimulate as much muscle gain as if you made the weight heavier and kept the sets to five to ten reps on average. Sure, you could do sets of 12, but you guys know what I mean. If your breathing is what's keeping you back, it's not a great hyper-chive exercise. Great breathing exercise. But we're not here to do cardio where you're going to get been quads. Next, if you're doing hacksquots in most cases, you want to take advantage of the fact that you can go a little bit more high rep because it raises you a bit better. Sure, you can do hacksquots with sets of five to ten, but a lot of times that much knee flexion without any hip help is a bit much of an isolation exercise and it doesn't feel 100% as safe for the quadriceps. You can totally do your hacksquots with sets of five to ten, but I recommend the best rep range for me on average for hacksquots is sets of 10 to 15 reps. 15 and up for me and my personal experience and most of folks I've trained with starts to become again a little bit more cardio and not enough heavy resistance training that actually trains the target muscles. For leg presses, the best range that I found is sets of 10 to 20. Again, you can do sets of five and sets of eight and leg press, but that's a bit heavy that's probably better reserved for squats. Anything above 20 reps is just cardio, but the leg press lets you sit down and braces you in. So there's a wide range through which you could use it or cycling somewhat with a hacksquot, but also giving you that 50 to 20 rep range to play with reveriation. Lastly, the term heavy leg extensions makes almost no sense to me. Why would you do something heavy in a position in which your body limits you from using heavy load and even trying very hard? Your quads activate better when you're heel and foot have something to press against, then just extending your knee against resistance. Heavy leg extensions are just not the best use of either heavy or leg extensions. You want to go heavy to squats, but if you wanted leg extensions, there are excellent exercises that you can do for variation in the higher rep ranges. You can do leg extensions for 10 or more reps, but the real money is 15 or even 20 to 30 reps. In leg extension sets, especially if you drop sets, supersets, my rep match reps, all of that stuff fries you out. Thus, you have a whole spectrum of which exercises to use more often when you're going heavier, which ones for intermediate loading, in which ones for higher reps, thus you can match the exercise to the loading and vice versa and get the most out of the movements as far as effectiveness and as far as safety. Lastly, if you're really serious about quad training and you want to take your quad training to the next level, buy yourself some weight lifting shoes. They don't have to be super expensive, but any weight lifting shoe that's literally in a sport of weight lifting, it's not like I'm saying, oh, a lifting shoe for lifting weights. It's a weight lifting one word shoe. If you google that, it's the shoes with the heel that rises as it goes. Those shoes are going to just completely upgrade your quad training to the next level. They allow an unbelievable amount of even support so that pushing through your toes and your heels is super super easy to do in almost intuitive. They provide you with a ton of stability and also by raising your heel, they extend your ankle mobility and let you get super deep stretching the quad without involving the lower back and the hips as much and thus making all of your quad training even more targeted for the quad.
